course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Energy and Related Environmental Issues
course.description: This course will introduce the basic concepts of the physical principles behind energy. Various forms of energy and their use (including electricity, fossil energy, nuclear power, various forms of renewable energy), and their impacts on the environment both from a global and a regional perspectives will be discussed. Issues related to energy conservation and related environmental issues in Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta (PRD) will be discussed. Students without the physics prerequisite but have taken PHYS 1001 or equivalent may seek instructor’s approval for enrolling in the course.
course.prerequisites: Level 3 or above in HKDSE 1/2x OR in HKDSE 1x Physics

reviews.author: Luweegee
reviews.title: Shittiest Common Core Course Ever (But Good Grade Though)
reviews.comment_content:
The content is pointless and disorganized. You are intended to learn about physics related to energy production and related issues, but the content is a crap of mess that I learn nothing useful at the end of semester. In this course, you’ll learn some thermodynamics, DSE physics (E3 module especially) and some social-related issues which are freaking pointless.

===Syllabus (In lecture no.)===
1. Introduction
2. Energy consumption & Population growth
3. Fossil fuels
4. Temperature & Heat
5~6. Thermodynamics of heat engines
7. Otto engine & Passenger cars
8. Diesel engine & Cargo ships
9. Jet engine & Air travel
-----Mid-Term (Lecture 1~9)-----
11. Electricity generation
12. Electricity power grid
13. Electric lighting
14. Energy storage & Home heating
15. Embodied energy in stuff
16~17. Nuclear energy
18. Water energy
19. Wind energy
20. Solar energy
21. Air pollution
22. Global warming & Climate change
-----Final (Lecture 11~22)-----

===Lecture Slides===
Let’s start with lecture slides. The slides are full of filler like whole slide of data tables (expect one for every few slides), pointless graphs and stock photos. To make things worse, they examine those filler tables and graphs in the mid-terms and finals. They seriously asked whether wind turbines kill more birds than cats and cars in the mid-term...

The slides also contains some typos, including missing variables in important equations and typos of scientist names like “Telsa”. The professors just freaking cram all the related information, no matter whether it’s useful or not, into the slides. So what you have at the end of the day is a slide full of filler in every few slide, some key points placed besides images scraped from Google and some formulas you need to know.

===How far this course derailed from its objectives===
Since this is common core, I get that professors want to add social issues to the course. But they FAIL miserably. Instead of trying to let us understand how important renewable energies really are, or how physics is related to everyday life, professors just stuff all the related data into lecture slides and expect magic happens. They lazily stuff factual and trivial information under HK and China context, and read the data from the tables. To be honest, I learn very little knowledge at the end. What I DID learn is how to make a cheatsheet though :)

===How professors lie to get you in===
In the first lecture, they claim “This is not a physics course. This is a course about using numbers, not adjectives”. THIS IS A BIG F*CKING LIE!!! They straight up jumped to teaching thermodynamics right after the add-drop period. In fact, I would say 75% of content are physics related so I don't know why the professor lied in the first place.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wong Kam Sing is the one of the SHITTIEST lecture you’ll meet in your UST years. Other lecturers are not going to be that good either. But please avoid Wong’s timeslots.

===Shit English===
His English is so full Hong Kong accent and stuttering that it’s really hard to compile a sentence from his words. He just pronounces some English words half the way through and repeats his last word while thinking. This results in masterpieces like:
Pronouncing “government” as “garment”
Pronouncing “ship” as “shit” (yes that’s true)
Pronouncing “flux” as “f*ck”

He also speaks in a weird intonation that he loves to raise the tone of the last word in the sentence. So sometimes he’ll break his voice at the end of sentence and it’s so funny. To be honest we are not expecting your English to be top-notch but at least make it understandable... So, expect majority of the class falling asleep or doing their own stuff half way through the lesson.

===Shit Teaching===
He just fail to explain concepts clearly. He just reads from the slides when "teaching" thermodynamics. He expects you have some background knowledge and straight up teaching super quickly and didn’t explain new stuff such (He successfully crammed two PHYS1112 lectures into one lecture).

He just read off slides just as we are blind. He even has got to the point of reading data out of data tables! Overall, he’s just very not enthusiastic and sometimes yell to students who are chatting with their friends. Please read your PHYS1111/PHYS1112 notes instead.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not gonna lie, this course is really good grade which kinda surprises me when the final grading is out. You can get A grade if your mid-term and exam is 1 SD above mean :)

===Distribution===
Mid-Term: 45%
Final: 55%
Bonus PRS questions:  5%

===Statistics===
Mid-Term:  Mean - 142.2/200 ; SD - 25.2
Final:  Mean - 254 ; SD - 63

===My Marks===
Mid-Term: 172/200 (+1.2SD)
Final: 303/400 (+0.77SD)
PRS Bonus: 5/5
Grade: A

===Test Papers Rules===
The tests are so BADLY-WRITTEN that you’ll feel angry.
You can bring one A-4 cheatsheet in both mid-term and final and the tests are not cumulative. For both mid-term and final, there are MC questions and long questions.

For MC, you’ll get 5 marks for correct answer, but deduct 1 mark per incorrect attempt (zero marks for no attempt though). They also give step marks very strictly in LQ generally. They will give no marks if you got something wrong in steps.

{Side Note: This rule generally applies if the test paper is not too difficult. It applied to the mid-term paper but the final paper was more lenient since final exam is hell}

===Shitty Questions===
The professors love to challenge us by NOT PUTTING important information in test papers to torture our souls.

For my mid-term exam, they PURPOSELY didn’t put the conversion between calorie and joules. They expect you to have this seemingly important information that the question will provide in your cheatsheet! I even asked the TAs to provide us the conversion but they refused. They say “We want to test your unit conversion so we didn’t add that”. F*ck that! If I cannot convert units, I’m still not going to calculate anything correctly if you provide “1 calorie = 4.18J” in the question! This question had become a test of how good your cheatsheets are, instead of how good your unit conversion skills are.

The final is just a train wreck. They expect you to know that the noble gas with atomic number 54 is Xenon. Really? Now they expect us to put a f*cking periodic table in my cheatsheet.

And the long questions occupying half of the total marks are so painfully difficult that no one I know can do all of them. They copied a stupid weird graph from Google and expect us to work out figures from that graph. I only know how to do 1 out of 4 LQs but still managed to get 127/200 marks… (I'm really surprised) Probably you may wanna write as much stuff as possible to bet they give you step marks.

===PRS Bonus Questions===
The professors know that if they didn’t add PRS question to end of every lesson, no one will be attending. They will ask a question at the end of each lesson. Those are pretty easy and you can answer them correctly even though you didn’t pay attention in the whole lesson.

Every correct answer scores 1 mark, 0.5 mark for incorrect and 0 mark for not answering.

===Advice===
The only good thing about this course is that it's really good grade. If you score 1 SD above mid-term and final and get nearly all the bonus PRS marks then you should have A- or A. Of course, you have to be confident that you don't screw up your tests.

I have a friend who got 1.8 SD above mean in mid-term but 0.3 SD above mean in final and he got A-. So the moral of story is don't screw up your final
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is also very light, almost to the point of none. There are homework for self-practice and not credit bearing. The only workload you’ll get is making cheatsheet and doing exercises. If you have sources, making cheatsheet shouldn’t be a huge problem.

===Conclusion===
I just don’t understand how come such a crappy course is a school sponsored common core course. Probably most of the money UST had given ends up in professors’ pockets ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

This course doesn't give you insights and knowledge. The only thing it gives you is good grades if you do well. Nothing more than that. F*ck this course

reviews.author: gossipgirl
reviews.comment_content: The content is very very boring and crappy. Given the course name and topic, it could have been made much more interesting. They say "This course is about numbers" but well, the theory and numerical part don't seem to make sense together and the large class size and 3 professors teaching just ruins it. If you're looking to take this course for S&T SSC, you're probably better off taking ENGG 1150. Although the workload might be high, but from what I've heard, grading is lenient.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is really really bad. The most boring lectures Ive ever attended. Not taught well at all. Most of the lectures are just reading out the slides without any meaning as such. Cant focus at all!
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading isn't very lenient. The exams follow the most ridiculous marking scheme Ive seen. MCQ's have a +5,-1 weightage and short answers have +10,0. Incorrect answers are given 0 and no partial credit is given in any circumstance.

Having said that getting a B+ isnt very hard. slightly more than mean should get you a B+. mean ~B
reviews.comment_workload: To be honest, the workload isn't much. A 2 sided cheat-sheet is allowed in both exams but it doesn't really make the course interesting or easier.

reviews.author: abhr
reviews.title: Crappiest course you could take in UST as a Common Core
reviews.comment_content: Absolutely boring topics covered. Too much of stats and data stuffed into the lecture slides that confuse and perplex when preparing for the exams. Relevancy or applications of the topics covered cannot be seen by most students, making the course content itself not very enjoyable to study.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are hard to concentrate in, especially with the 3 professors' accents. Monotonous lectures in classes of 300+ students, best class to do anything except PHYS1003 for almost all students. A typical class comprises of either slides being simply read off word by word in class, or abstract concepts being explained without any mention in the lecture slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS 5%, Midterm 40%, Final 55%
Unreasonable grading with respect to the effort put in to learning the course content. Although a cheat sheet is allowed in the exams, it is of no use whatsoever. The paper has 2 parts- MC Questions with a ridiculous +5, -1 marking scheme and long answer questions with 10-20 marks awarded for correct answer (depending on question) and none for wrong. The curve comes absolutely ridiculous with 2-3 bell curves and high mean and S.D. that make it hard to assess one's performance.  People usually take Common Cores to bring their grades up, but really cannot expect that with this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Nothing extra besides preparing for the midterm and final, but the large number of slides given do require a lot of time to prepare for.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: One of the Dumbest CC
reviews.comment_content:
A “mixed baby” of Physics, General Science and Liberal Studies.

Every lesson, every chapter, every topic...Whatever you could think of...Dumped as arbitrary clusters into disordered and disorganised Power Point slides.

Having taken this course was WORSE than eating McDonald for ninety days straight ahead.

Like what you may get if you link up digital pronunciations of random words from Online Oxford Dictionary in a string.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: a large-shit course, gain nth but shittest outcome from the worst professor 黃錦聖
reviews.comment_content:
This is a school-sponsored common course course (S&T) and  the course only allows students with previous knowledge of Physics (DSE) to enroll in. The content covered in this course includes a wide range of aspects but students find difficulty to figure out the linkage between each topic.

You will find out the course is a nightmare since you will get faked by the professor, saying that " this is not a physics course".

The topics covered in the mid-term exam include population growth, heat, thermodynamics, engines of vehicles and ships, and flying(mentioning the flying principles and Bernouli equation). Previous knowledge of thermodynamics covered in PHYS1112 (General Physics I with Calculus) is recommended for this course since the concepts are just the same. The PowerPoint slides are just a piece of mess and provide limited explanation of the relevant concepts.  You have to know the functions and the mechanisms of each cycle and just to apply the calculation into practice. Some strange calculations are included in the first few lectures.

The final exam includes much more topics, but students should get familiar if they studied such concepts in detail during DSE. Some E&M concepts learnt in DSE are included, while the content learnt in DSE- E3 are covered. Such topics include nuclear fission and nuclear fusion, wind,solar and hydro power, electrical lighting , pollution and global warming. However you should be careful that there are some calculations required for clear understanding.

The powerpoint slides are just too messy and involve lots of unnecessary data, information and pictures which are not examined during examinations. The slides are generally arranged in a chaotic way and it is recommended to figure out the key concepts, operating mechanisms of different energy type and reactions and key calculations in each slide to prepare for making of your own cheatsheet for examinations.

But please spend some days before the exams to identify the content covered during the boring lectures and prepare for the cheatsheet which requires you to be familiar with periodic table, unit conversion,calculus etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is just way too bad, especially his English and way of delivery. The lectures are just too boring and useless.
The professor shows lots of hesitation and uncertainties during lectures since he fails to speak in a fluent and proper manner. His broken and Hong-Kong style English makes him difficult to grab students attention and arouse interest. His pronunciation is flat and plain without any intonation and stress, as well as he fails to read a word correctly. It seems he didn't prepare for the lectures and speak in a chaotic and unorganized way. International students will probably find difficulty to understand what he is trying to speak since he is just a local, like local who doesn't know English.

Examples of poor English:
This is a large "shit" -> ship
The petrol "unging" -> engine
Power "pan1" -> plant

Students recommend the professor to make a IELTS attempt to judge his English speaking ability and improve English.

Overall, Wong Kam Sing this terrible guy, please don't teach anymore, go and have your research or practice your English before you are getting into the coffin.

He is just a mean,rude,nonsense and irresponsible guy. Do no preparation before lectures, being rude to his MPhil TAs and IAs,  and the students who were coming just for the PRS.

Prof 黃錦聖 講野根本組織唔到，應該有語癌要揾言語治療師治理
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is generally shit.
For MC questions, a correct answer rewards 5 marks , no mark given for unattempted questions.
However you should realise that a one-mark penalty will be given to a wrong MC answer, which can be humiliated and painful if you get too many questions wrong. If you find difficulty to identify the answer just don't answer the question to secure marks.

Generally students get proper marks and even you are slightly below mean in mid-term, try to score higher marks and your grade will probably get secured.

The lectures are generally boring and the professors with poor English try to grab attentions from students, so they adopt PRS in each lecture. The PRS questions are generally easy and if you attend the lectures with your friends, just spend your time on other stuff and wait for the PRS response.

General marking scheme:
Mid term 45%
Final 55%
PRS during lectures additional 5%
1 mark for correct option 0.5 mark for wrong option no mark for unattempt

Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is just preparing for exams and work on understanding the concepts and preparing for your own cheatsheet.

Even my high school teacher Mr 廢林明 knew what he was teaching and cover the basics of the content LOL

reviews.author: Toiletpaper
reviews.title: Don’t fucking sign up this course if you haven’t studied physics in high school
reviews.comment_content:
Nothing special if you had studied physics in high school. You won’t be able to learn anything new except the four processes of thermodynamic.
Content is almost the same as the high school syllabus (chapters for electromagnetism, heat transfer, electricity, gas laws and the energy elective in DSE).
Gotta have clear concept and previous knowledge in physics to support your learning. So dont sign up this course if you hadnt studied physics, you would get fucked up cuz others studying this course is from science and engineering school.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professors cant speak proper english lol. Plus the teaching isnt useful, they just read out the powerpoints and demonstrate some simple experiments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Dont know about it yet. Just had my midterm.
Just saying, not bragging but just for reference, I studied physics in high school and got 5* in physics, i still got quite a number of uncertain answers in the mc, while one of the long question invovled enthalpy in chemistry, k, i was expecting thermoequilibrium.
I can tell you that without my previous knowledge, i would most likely fuck up real hard. But still i fucked up.
A big middle finger for this course.
My senior friend got A last semester, he was one sd above mean.
My another friend who sign up this course and has no previous knowledge in physics, ended up sitting in the examination hall dreaming and turned in a blank answer book.
And the policy’s a lil bitch cuz if you answer a mc wrong, -1 mark for you, answer a mc right, +5 marks for you. Expected value is 0.2 good luck.
reviews.comment_workload:
Zero workload. I went throught all the homework which is in a style of application question but it wasnt useful in long question section, it helps to make clear your concept tho.
IPRS gives you 5% bonus which equals to one sub grade, don’t sign up the 9 am lesson.
Midterm 45% Final 50%
Good luck signing up it.

reviews.author: no_name_provide
reviews.title: Fragmented courses
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is totally fragmented. Just see the following topics covered in this course before midterm:

1. Population growth
2. Origin of fossil fuels
3. Thermodynamics (Temperature and engine)
4. (a) Energy dissipation in cars, ships and airplanes
          (including formula for air resistance, etc.)
    (b) Engines in cars, ships and airplanes
    (c) How airplanes fly in sky?
5. Acid rain

And the midterms cover topics ranging from entropy (physics) to enthalpy (chemistry). WTF? The content is so fragmented and nothing special you can learn from this course except learning how airplanes fly in air and preparing yourself for studying thermodynamics in PHYS 1112. (So, I recommend you to take this course together with PHYS1112, if you don't have any other SSC-S&T CC alternatives)

p.s. As u might read from the first comment, THIS IS A PHYSICS COURSE. But I want to do a modification on this statement. THIS IS A PHYSICS + CHEMISTRY COURSE. We have 1 LQ on chemistry (enthalpy change) in midterm and my friend w/o chem bg completely fuck up that Qs. DO NOT COME WITHOUT CHEMISTRY BACKGROUND!

reviews.author: NickName28
reviews.title: PHYS 1003 - Cheat Sheets and Unrelated Course Issues
reviews.comment_content:
Content is fragmented, extremely wide, and not that informative. If you have a passing interest in the topic, you probably are aware of significant portions of the course, barring the scientific concepts and formulae. A large portion of the content is irrelevant overall (meaning basically every table, graph, or case study) and can be skipped. The content isn't too much nor too complex, and in the end, having little content isn't that bad - it helps it all fit on your cheat sheet.

As a note, if you don't fully understand it already, the thermodynamics section will probably not make much sense. At least not if you have the world's worst substitute come in. Just learn it from Hyperphysics - it's far better at explaining. Don't bother worrying about why the formulae work either, it'll just waste your time. (I hate not knowing these things, and this bothered me a lot, but was the best decision. Adiabatic formulae are terrible.)

And seriously. Ignore the tables. If you get the rambling professor I did, nothing he says is useful. You don't need to waste your precious cheat sheet space on writing down that Venezuela has the world's largest oil reserves or whatever. No one cares about the Chinese infrastructure projects - they'll give you different case studies in the exam anyway.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was the worse part of this course. If you can't write good cheat sheets, or require good teachers to properly learn, this course is not for you. The teacher barely explained anything useful, and instead spends his time on irrelevant things. He teaches in a very boring manner - the most exciting moment in class I remember was when I got a PRS question wrong and he explained it. It wasn't exciting, which says a lot. I nearly fell asleep in these lessons, even when I wasn't tired in other ones.

He'll spend 10 minutes reading out a table and explaining every single thing you can extrapolate from it (which barely showed up in the exam beyond some general trends mentioned elsewhere) or spend five minutes writing out a complicated formula from beginning to end (when none of the intermediate steps are useful), and then skip straight past the concepts that might be confusing. Some of these concepts were not relevant, which makes me question why he bothered including them at all.

As an example, microstates were mentioned once in relation to entropy. They were not explained at all; not what a microstate is nor what counts as a separate microstate. Before the exam, I checked the homework, and the singular question on microstate was thus confusing. I panicked a bit - I had no clue what these were and the internet wasn't being cooperative. In the end, after meeting with the TAs, it turned out that this wasn't necessary anyway.

The substitute we got for the two hardest lessons (thermodynamics) was the worst teacher I've ever had. Incomprehensible, useless, and incapable of explaining anything properly. His idea of explaining how formula changed was "and then you use calculus" or "with some math", ignoring important parts like the necessary substitution. He's just... bad.

Overall, expect bad time management, a lack of explanation in class (but go seek out the TAs, they're actually good at explaining things and will help) and boring lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Despite the bad ratings in the other two categories, I would actually recommend this course to anyone wanting some SSC S&T credits. Because it's not that hard. The final exam mean was 254/400, SD of 63. I got 349, an A. Why? The cheat sheet. In this course, your cheat sheet is your best friend. Because you can fit everything relevant on those two sides you get to bring in to the exam - I didn't do any memorization studying, merely a quick reread of the slides before the exam, and still got an A. Good thing about the final is that it is non-cumulative; nothing before the mid-term matters.The mid-term was similarly easy, although I don't remember the grades. I did get an A with the same strategy, though.

Oh, and in addition, the PRS grades are a bonus mark in this course. 45% midterm, 55% final, 5% extra bonus for PRS. And they are easy enough you can get at least 75% right, giving an extra ~4% overall.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much to say here. No homework, no assignment, no attendance  needed even, as the PRS grade is a bonus. The disjointed and wide nature of the course means that after the midterm, nothing really relates to anything else. So skipping a lesson won't affect your ability to understand the next lesson. The only work is the cheat sheets, which for me just involved going through all the lesson notes and combining what seemed important.

reviews.author: Mango Pudding
reviews.title: Easy course to get good grades, but don't repeat my mistakes
reviews.comment_content:
=== Lecture topics ===
► Energy & Population growth
► Energy consumption & Fossil Fuels
► Temperature & Heat (PHYS1112 stuff)
► Laws of thermodynamics (PHYS1112 stuff)
► Heat engines in our daily lives (PHYS1112 stuff)
► Otto, diesel & jet engines
► Car, ship & air transportation
► Electricity generation
► Electricity distribution
= (Midterm content ends here) =
► Batteries & Electric cars
► Energy consumption in our daily lives
► Water power
► Wind power
► Solar power
► Nuclear power
► Environmental impacts from non-renewable energy
► Global warming & Climate change

=== Opinions ===
Except for thermodynamics, the content is very easy, though I lost interest halfway through. People say it's very similar to DSE PHY E3, still, the content can be easily picked up by anyone from any background, again, except thermodynamics. If you've studied PHYS1112 then you'll roll through that portion, albeit with some minor differences in sign and notation that may confuse you initially.

Honestly, since they got rid of the final exam this semester, I stopped taking notes during lectures after the midterm (around when they were on water power) and worked on the project in the lecture theatre instead. If they keep the same arrangement in future semesters, I'd recommend doing so as well to save some time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
At first, he tried to make the lectures interactive with discussions and asking questions, but then just turned into your regular lectures as fewer and fewer people attend.

There are usually physics demonstrations for each lecture, so sit up front to get the best view. (Though no one did as I reckon they all got intimidated by the cold calls to answering questions)

He is friendly in answering your questions on the project and actively listens to feedback from the "exit ticket" that we can send digitally should we have opinions on the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
► Midterm 40%
• Statistics: Mean 119.86; SD 33.79; Median 125
• I got 138/200, which is fair as I panicked, managed to confuse myself and ended up not finishing.

Two A4 *HAND WRITTEN* cheat sheets, I'd recommend grouping all formulas and their parameters together on one page to not have to flip through the notes constantly like I had to. Be clear on what unit the parameters are in and what they stand for. You need to plug many numbers into the equations, which can easily lead to mistakes. I have plugged in the wrong values and even missed parameters. Side rant, they designed the midterm such that all information and subquestions for a problem were grouped and given blank pages to answer on. It was inconvenient to flip back and forth to get the info for your formulas.

► Group project report 25%
► Poster presentation 25%
(A casual convention-like event, not the traditional everyone looks at you kind of presentation, see workload section for detail)
• Project total score statistics: Mean 89.34; Median 90.74; LQ 86.8; UQ 95; The scores are very tight
• My group got 97.7/100 and seeing how tight the distribution is, I reckon the midterm is much more deterministic for the grade

► Question of the day 10% (See workload section for detail)
The three lowest scoring QotD will be dropped

I got A- in the end, and it seems like the midterm is much more deterministic of the final grade given that you don't do the project haphazardly
reviews.comment_workload:
Question of the day after every lecture, but unlike iPRS, you do not need to be present at the lecture theatre and just submit the Canvas quiz before the deadline. These are very simple and easy to complete.

Homework questions are for preparing for the midterm only, no submission is required but is highly recommended, especially for the thermodynamics topics.

Then there's the group project. 5-page report (+some pages for figures and references) plus an A1 poster. Sounds easy, but the execution feels like a mess (at least in my mind, whereas my teammates are not stressed at all).

The project proposal was submitted before the midterm, and you have a month to finish the report. In reality, they took a long time to give feedback on your proposal on Canvas, and still, their feedback wasn't helpful and didn't remind us that our scope is too broad and wouldn't be ideal for the short report. My advice is to not wait for that and approach the instructor directly so that you could work on the report early.

For someone who hasn't worked on a report before, I feel like they didn't give enough pointers on how it should be written early enough, up until one week before the report submission when they did the project consultation during the lecture. Only at that point, our group realised we had too many research questions and had to restructure and rewrite the majority of the report. It would've been much better had they conducted the project consultation earlier, or moved the content to the project briefing session.

Lastly, the A1 poster and poster presentation. We had two days after the project report deadline to design and submit the softcopy of the poster, which is a summary of each part of the report. My advice is to have it in point form, with fewer and larger words and more graphics, so that it is more interesting and easier to read. And if you are willing to pay $80, you can get the A1 poster professionally printed at the MTPC print shop (Room 3104, lift 2). Otherwise, you could just stick multiple A4s together.

The poster presentation session is more like a casual convention than one group presenting in front of the entire class. All groups put up their posters in the lecture theatre, and then instructors and TAs will randomly come to your poster and ask questions. One groupmate stands by the poster while the others walk around the theatre visiting other groups. You do not need to memorise a script, just be familiar with your report, or just pull up the document on your phone when needed. Be relaxed and see what others have done.

reviews.author: alalal
reviews.title: PHYS major perspective
reviews.comment_content:
Before the midterm, the course covers the principles behind energy production. There will be around 4 lectures covering heat (pdV work, gas pressure, heat engines and refrigerators etc), which is the most challenging part of the entire course. If you have taken PHYS1112 before this course, you should be quite familiar with these concepts. If you have no PHYS1112 background, be prepared to spend more time understanding and drilling those parts before the midterm exam since it may be challenging to understand them the first time. Knowledge from the heat unit of HKDSE may be helpful.
After the midterm, the focus shifts to introducing different types of energy. Knowledge from EM and radiation of HKDSE may be helpful. The course was wrapped up by going through some environmental impacts of general energy production on the world.
Overall, the course covers quite a wide range of knowledge that we may not have known about energy and energy production. I also feel myself being more aware of the environment quality.  However, from an exam-oriented point of view, I experienced difficulty finding the focus of the course and each topic, so I won't know what to put on the cheat sheets and what to revise more. To conclude, it's basically an ENVS course that tests physics things. Take it if you are interested in both.
Please refer to the attached course schedule or other reviews for the list of topics taught.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This is Prof. Jaeck's first semester and first course at HKUST. Perhaps because of that, he values our feedback a lot. He has a thing called the "exit ticket", which is an anonymous and non-compulsory survey we fill out at the end of every lesson. We can rate his lecture, ask questions and give constructive opinions there, and he would read our feedback and make suitable changes in teaching style. You can already tell how much of a devoted and passionate instructor he is from this. He tried really hard to keep his lectures entertaining, by sharing his personal encounters in Germany, showing us videos that he found, 1-2-3 GO! games (which we just chuck whatever ideas we have in our mind about a topic into the Zoom chat room), and even breakout room discussions. Regrettably, the interaction activities didn't work out well in Zoom, but he still managed to catch our attention (at least mine).
Overall, he is a very dedicated instructor. He has a slight German accent, but I think it's more charismatic than difficult to understand, so it's not a problem. Honoured to be one of his guinea pigs :)
By the way, the IA of the course organised everything super well. He is also open to any questions, so feel free to ask the IAs if you are less interested to ask the professors questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
-- Midterm exam -- 40% --
50 mins for 20 conceptual questions and 3 sets (a total of 8 questions) of computational questions. Covers lecture 1 - 10. 1 sheet (2 pages) of A4 sized cheat sheet is allowed. Suggest getting yourself familiar with all of the equations taught and jot all of them down on your cheat sheet. Jot down some facts about different types of engines too. Revision of homework is essential.
-- Final exam -- 55% --
50 minutes for 35 conceptual questions, and another 50 minutes for 4 sets (a total of 12) computational questions.
Covers lecture 11 - 22. 2 sheets (4 pages in total) of A4 sized cheat sheets are allowed. Suggest you jot down all data that are present in lecture notes. Completion of homework and revision of IPRS questions are essential. A lot of the answers to the conceptual questions are what I thought to be some fun facts that will not be tested, that's why I performed worse in conceptual questions. Write down as many facts as you can in cheat sheets. For computational questions, be more familiar with changes of units and all equations.
-- IPRS quizzes -- 5% --
One question per lecture. 1 mark for a correct answer, 0.5 marks for an incorrect answer, 0 marks for no answer. Pay attention to class and be careful then you can probably answer them right.

Detailed statistics of exam scores are attached below.
For me:
Midterm: 90/100 (+1.31 SD)
Final: 104/120 (+1.12 SD)
IPRS: 89% (sorry I didn't pay much attention in class)
Final grade: A
(I guess the mean is B, which, I think, is quite good)
reviews.comment_workload:
2 lectures (1.5 hrs each) per week, no tutorial sessions and compulsory assignments. There are non-compulsory 1-hour help desk sessions in Zoom every week, which are like office hours, except it is a TA instead of professors who will be answering your questions. There are homework problems that we don't need to hand in, so I just did those when preparing for the exams. Very light workload overall.

CAUTION: As you may have guessed from the score distribution, many students in this course are either in physics major or have a strong physics background. If you don't think you do, or if you only have had your first exposure to physics through PHYS1001 and want a good grade, think twice, thrice, and quarce before taking this course. If you still choose to register for this course, be prepared to be spending a lot of time and effort catching up, to have results on par with people who have more physics background.

reviews.comment_workload: only have iprs, dun have any assignment. little workload before the mid term and final, preparing for the cheatsheet. (but u can take the other's cheatsheet from the source)

reviews.author: LeoLiao
reviews.title: 究極垃圾伏course
reviews.comment_content: 廢到不得了，中學有修phy/chem就識曬concept，就算無都只會學到一d google都有，factual既野，根本唔係phy。唔明點解要教，浪費時間
reviews.comment_teaching: 英文講得難聽之餘照讀ppt，你唔訓著當我輸
reviews.comment_grading:
雖然大部分人都話好grade而個派A range率的確係高，但係nds同部分為刷grade既人會拉到個mean好高，想要踩mean攞b range其實個付出不比其他科少，奉勸唔好因為A range闊而reg。

考試cheat sheet非常重要，變相只係考你眼力同搜尋能力，想體驗做應試機器不妨試試，保證你考完之後都唔知自己做過d咩。

midterm below 0.7 sd 佔45%
final above mean a bit 佔55%
prs only took 30% 佔bonus 5%
turns out B
reviews.comment_workload: 無功課，但逼你上垃圾堂take 計分prs，慘過做功課。建議臨完前20分鐘先去take。今個sem變左剩係5% bonus，即使唔take曬問題亦不大

reviews.author: Siumaigor
reviews.comment_content: Actually many complicated physics concept are involved, but if you know how to make a decent cheat sheet, you'll pass the course by just substituting the the numbers to the equation.
reviews.comment_teaching: He teaches horribly and you can never understand his English. He can't even read the powerpoint properly. If you expect you will learn something from the prof, you will learn nothing but the ability to study by yourself by reading textbooks and googling.
reviews.comment_grading:
The PRS are straightforward and can get half of the mark even you get the answers wrong. The midterm is yet to be graded so I am not sure.

Mid-term Exam:                  45%

Final Exam:                        55%

Plus 5% bonus by PRS quizzes

Rules for PRS:

Full Marks for correct answers, half marks for incorrect answers, 0 marks for no answers.
Marks will not be counted during the add-drop period.
reviews.comment_workload: Coming to class to do the PRS is the main workload and you have to self-study everything before midterm which is also tough. No homework has to be submitted, but some are left as an exercise for you.

reviews.author: Johnjohnjohn
reviews.title: Good grade if u are hardworking
reviews.comment_content:
Content are not hard in general but very wide. Main divided into thermodynamics, electricity, power generation and pollution. Have both simple equations and knowledge include, but as cheat sheet (2 A4 pages) is allowed, no need to memorize. But the making of cheat sheet is very painful. Sometimes have self reading material in the ppt but I read through them quickly.

There will be QRS before the end of each lecture, but it is just for extra 5% of the total grade.

But to be honest there is a great advantage for science or engineering student (or DSE students who took physics) to take the course, where most of the content are taught before.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very normal, not very good but not bad. But as the lecture took place at LTA, only part of the students are paying attention (not include me). There are some experiments during lecture to let u understand the teaching material (and to wake us up), but just a few of them.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad. Mid term and final both above mean a bit have a final grade of B+. But the paper marking is very very very bad. If possible try your best to go to the paper checking section, there is a great chance that u can have a (great amount of) mark regained (True story: my friend who wrote the same answer in a long question as me gain back 20 marks from a question where he received 0 point previously).
reviews.comment_workload:
Nearly zero workload. Only mid term and final (both MC and long questions) plus QRS (extra score). There are homework but no need to hand in, which is just for revision before exams (the homework is harder than the exam but is a must to do or read its solution since some question from the exam will be very similar to homework).
For exams also what u have to do is just read through all the notes and make cheat sheets. (But the amount of content is quite large so beware of the time... Like have 9 ppt for mid term and 12 ppt for final, each ppt may contains 30 to 80 pages...)

reviews.author: XD yau
reviews.title: Good Course
reviews.comment_content:
before midterm:
use of energy by human
fossil fuel
car
engine(thermodynamics)
air transport

after midterm:
lighting and power grid
embodied energy
nuclear energy
renewable energy(wind, solar, tidal, water, etc)
air pollution
global warming

Actually they are quite interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Actually, the content are quite interesting.
So, it would be good to attend their lecture.
There are some experiment in some lecture so that you wont sleep.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade.
Only midterm, final and iprs. Both midterm and final consist of only MC and long Q.
For MC, just need to copy everything in cheatsheet and you can almost master all MC. Some question may be quite in depth(especially in final) so be sure that you copied EVERYTHING. Some MC may just ask you about math.
Long Q mainly just test your mathematical skills, and some are related to DSE physics. Doing optional HW may help you much.
Iprs consist of only quite simple MC. Even you answered wrong, you still get half credits. So remember to attend lecture.
p.s. things tested in midterm will not be tested in final:)
Score:
iprs:5%
midterm:45%
final:50%
Grade:A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much at all, just midterm and final (and iprs). No other things at all.
Just go through powerpoint carefully and copy everything in cheatsheet before midterm and final is ok.
Remember to attend EVERY lecture because there is iprs in EVERY lecture.

reviews.author: Kabe
reviews.title: This course is badly designed
reviews.comment_content:
This course first talk about stupid factual stuff, then thermodynamics (only good part in this course I guess), then different types of engine, electricity, embodied energy, nuclear, wind, water, solar energy, finally air pollution and global warming.
The powerpoint is broken, fragmented, and there is about 3/4 of the powerpoint that is meaningless in my opinion, those are just random stupid statistics that have no help to our learning. What's even worse is that meaningful content (perhaps 3 slides per lecture) also show up like crap in the powerpoint, so it take quite a lot of effort to filter out useful content.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is bad, really bad, especially the professors I encountered this semester are quite passionate so I am particularly disgruntled about the teaching. They are just reading the powerpoint, and as I mentioned before those powerpoint are crap, which make this even worse. They spoke without any passion and soul, and the lesson is at 9am, so I fell asleep every lesson (before I gave up attending it).
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 45%
Final 55%
PRS 5% bonus

For midterm and final, a two-sided A4 cheat sheet is allowed.

For midterm, I got 189.5/200,
Mean: 146/200, SD: 26
Mean and SD are before grading adjustment so the actual mean should be higher than this.
For final, I got 339/400,
Mean: 252/200, SD: 57
Finally got an A+. The midterm and final are both easy given that you have a cheat sheet. Do the assignment (or put the answer of it in the cheatsheet) can help you get through the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are assignments for self-practice but not for handing in. PRS for attendance every lesson but you can always go at the last 5 minutes for the PRS so actually there is no need to attend the lesson.
For midterm and final, cheat sheet does all. There is a lot of stupid things in this course that does not worth remembering so you better prepare a good cheat sheet. Those stupid stuff are actually gonna be tested in the exam.

reviews.comment_content: The contents were sort of too much for me, and they were quite boring. Although a cheatsheet was allowed in the exam, it seemed that those tested were never on the sheet...
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor spoke with a strong accent and he was always reading the slides directly instead of "teaching". But he's responsive to students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading: A range is not very difficult. But getting an A+ really needs more efforts.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was really light, since homework was not mandatory. It was one of the biggest attractions of this course.

reviews.author: 別問我是誰
reviews.title: 內容極豐富既 physics common core
reviews.comment_content:
內容橫跨 energy (每樣energy都有n版slides講解, 同埋連圖講原理/開採&收集方法), environment 去到最後 electricity。每一堂份lecture note 大概廿幾三十版，total有22份。

成個course 無 past paper (因為professor從來無upload過), 只係得lecture 既幾條 in-class PRS quiz (計分), 自修用 homework, 同埋考之前既 review questions 可以用黎估下佢點出題法。

MT 比1張2版A4 cheat sheet, final 就2張4版, final 唔會考番mt前教既野。
reviews.comment_teaching: 本身個course都悶 (內容太豐富同分散)，professor 大部分時間都係跟slides講 (間唔中會有實驗睇/睇片)。多數人都做自己野，到差唔多夠鐘就拎PRS出黎答quiz。
reviews.comment_grading: MT above 1 sd, final below 0.74 sd, turn out B
reviews.comment_workload: 頭先亦提過，內容太豐富同分散，幾乎每張slide都有n個細節／重點要記，整cheat sheet 都要用唔少時間。

reviews.comment_grading:

reviews.comment_workload: Normal workload for UST with two projects. But it takes some time to prepare a good cheat sheet for exam too.

Homework optional

-Individual report x1 (word limit 500) 18%
>>佢每一堂都會出1-2條同當日lecture有關嘅open-ended question，所以如果你早見到有覺得寫得過嘅question嘅話就可以連add-drop都未過就已經寫好，如果去到最尾先見到就真係得個一個禮拜寫。

**sem中要交好短嘅proposal

If you have a physics background, then this course won't be hard for you.

I have to admit that the Professor has a nice teaching heart and is willing to convey all the things he knows to the students. He enjoys solving students' problems and would try his very best to clarify some of the misunderstandings the students.

The TAs qualities are very diversified. Some are very serious but some are lazy and reluctant to talk to students.

reviews.author: sleepingbag
reviews.comment_content:
There are different topics related to energy. Some are more theoretical such as calculating the entropy, others are more application based such as some engines used in real life.

Apart from going through lecture slides, the professor also prepared several experiments to conduct them during the lecture. The experiments are really fun and catch people's attention.

Lastly there is a final report. If you put effort into it, you could learn a lot throughout the process. You could still spend less time on it, but I think ust students should really cherish the opportunity to learn knowledge not related to their major. Though it's just a common core, it is indeed an interesting course to take.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Jaeck designed different fun experiments for every lecture. He also makes every point clear and concise. If you have further questions, he is also really willing to support you.

Some funny things happened during the lecture was that he would wake students up when they fell asleep. If you chat too loud, he would also remind you about your voice. I think those monkeys should show more respect to the professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
I must say it's a really good grading course. Workload sound scary but it's actually not. So in general the course is really good grading.

The difficult part of this course would be the midterm exam. It consists of both calculation and some application based question. For your reference I got A- in PHYS1112, and I think the exam is between medium and hard.

The quiz during the lecture only occupy for a small proportion of the final score. So it's actually a pretty chill quiz.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quiz + Midterm + Final Report

I spent more time on final report because one of my teammate couldn't meet the internal deadline and keep giving fake promise. But I worked well with another teammate and wrote up 80% of the report together.

Quiz almost contains no workload.

Midterm is pretty hard a takes me a week to study. But studying a midterm in any course for a week sounds pretty normal.

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: The Very Typical Grade-spamming Course
reviews.comment_content:
Basically the same with those reviews said before:

L1: Introduction and Review of energy
L2: Population growth and Energy consumption
L3: Fossil fuels
L4: Temperature and Heat
L5: Thermodynamics of heat engine I
L6: Thermodynamics of heat engine II
L7: Otto engine and Passenger cars
L8: Diesel engine and Cargo ships
L9: Jet engine and Air travel
L10: Environmental impacts of burning fossil fuels
L11: Electricity generation
L12: Electric power grid
L13: Electric lighting
L14: Energy storage and Home heating/cooling
L15: Embodied energy in “stuff”
L16: Nuclear energy I
L17: Nuclear energy II
L18: Water energy
L19: Wind energy
L20: Solar energy
L21: Air pollution
L22: Global warming and Climate change

Most of the content are general knowledge. According to the TAs, the lectures regarding Thermodynamics are especially hard. My experience shows that the parts regarding Thermodynamics are really crammed (and given by Professor Sou's teaching, will probably be hard to understand)...

Which is simply not the case if you've studied PHYS1112. So, the advice is to take PHYS1112 before you decide to spam some grade/CGA in taking this course. For those who've taken MECH2310 (Thermodynamics), the content difficulty on thermodynamics should be even comical.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As others have already said, Professor Sou is the typical PPT reader when teaching course materials. He has some Hong Kong accent, but is generally acceptable. You can simply read the course notes and wait for the PRS polling if you are bored with his teaching though.

Professor Sou sometimes also include his own research results/products in his lectures, and to be honest, it's really pathetic to make a potential researcher to teach in this kind of boring courses.

The performance of TAs are unexpectedly good though. During the lessons, one of the TA made good effort in answering my questions, usually extended beyond the course materials.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS polling: 5% (16/18)
Midterm: 40% (85/100, mean 68.82, SD 14.22)
Final: 55% (98/120, mean 87.75, SD 14.40)

The PRS polling is generally easy, but you may want to pay extra caution in calculation questions. Sometimes typical DSE Physics MC tricks (like the fact that transformers don't work for DC current) can put down waves of students, and these are usually the hardest PRS questions throughout the course.

This year both the midterm and final are full MC exams, with the final don't cover those covered in midterm. Apparently they want to eliminate some people in order to pull the curve for grading, so the MC questions in the final are made unchangeable after you submitted it (like PHYS1112), and they've added loads of trivial information into the final, a fact mentioned by some previous reviews. If you can adapt to this kind of quiz bowl-style questions, it would be a piece of cake. I think someone on MSSSUG said that the questions are merely English versions of junior secondary exam questions.

Finally get a A- for the course. Some said that you can already expect a A- or A if you get 1SD above the mean in exams. My experience shows that the threshold may be even more lenient. After all, PHYS1003 is widely recognized as a grade spamming course.
reviews.comment_workload: Basically zero workload. Homework is provided for self-learning, though you are encouraged to do some homework before exams, as I think nobody's going to spend real effort on a grade-spamming course during non-exam periods...

The mean of midterm and final is both high, and that's why even if you have high marks, it doesn't necessarily bring you to a very good grade. reviews.author: aict
reviews.title: Good class and grade
reviews.comment_content: Very closely related to E3 in most of the chapters. It would be easier if you studied E3 in DSE Physics
reviews.comment_teaching: Great teaching, a lot of explanations and even in-class demonstrations, which is definitely rare as most teachers play a video instead. He is very dedicated to answering questions as well as explaining concepts. The explanations are also clear and easy to understand, definitely recommend him as a instructor for this course
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 170/200
Final 232/250
Poll 17.5/21
Final grade A
Both the midterms and finals are easy so the mean is very high as many people get extremely high marks. Beware if your physics foundation wasn't good as it is easy to fall below the mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low workload. There is an polling question for each lecture and there is no graded assignment. The only tedious thing to do is that you need to hand-write your cheat sheets (typing not allowed). You are also allowed to access your lecture notes and the search function in pdf readers so do make full use of it during the midterm/exam.

All questions are in multiple-choice with 5 marks for each correct answer, you can also to forfeit the question if you do not know the answer as 1 mark will be deducted from the total for a wrong answer. You are also unable to view previous questions.

There is not as much calculation involved as expected. Most of the multiple choices involve questions related to information in lecture notes, students that have weaker math ability do not need to worry much. Even if there is calculation, it mostly involves plugging variables into the correct formula instead of complex calculation.

There is optional homework provided for every 2-3 lectures. These homework questions will occasionally appear in midterm/exam, so try to do them and understand how to solve the question before the exam.

reviews.comment_grading:
"Good grades but high mean"

About me:
Year 1 DSE Physics (E2E4) 5*

Grades: My score/Total (Mean, standard score)
Mid term: 165/200 (140, +0.73)
Final 238/250 (198, +1.14)
Polling: 4.5/5

Final grade : A

The exam is easy (but the mean is high too). You are allowed to prepare 4 pages of cheat sheet and look at lecture notes. Basically as long as you copy out all the formulas and know their physical meaning, and know where to look for things in the lecture notes, then you are good to go.

Midterm is quite a bit harder than finals, especially if you did not know thermodynamics and heat engines in advanced. The course is extremely fast paced and requires a bit of effort to understand.

Overall, the mean is quite high. If you are happy with a B+ then this course is definitely for you. However, if you want an A+ and you are prone to careless mistakes, then you might not want to take this course.

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: Requires Good Physics Background
reviews.comment_content:
It is like the elective 3 of DSE Physics, but with much more contents.
Syllabus:

Overview of Energy
Energy Consumption and Population Growth
Fossil Fuels and its Environmental Impacts
Temperature and Heat
Thermodynamics of Heat Engines
Otto Engines and Diesel Engines
Cars, Ships and Air Travelling
Cargo Ships

Electricity Generation and Power Grid
Lighting
Heating and Cooling
Embodied Energy in Items
Nuclear, Hydro, Tidal, Wind and Solar Power
Air Pollution
Global Warming

Although the course has no conditions other than getting level 3+ in DSE Physics, however, it is strongly suggested to *finish* PHYS1112 first before you take this course. It would help you to get over the barrier of Thermodynamics and Engine efficiency.
(DO NOT take both courses together as this course teaches thermodynamics before midterm while PHYS1112 teaches it at the last few lectures before final!)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The PowerPoint of this course tells you what is the meaning of "double edge blade". The slides are mostly filled with contents, but simply *too many contents*.
It is good to have a lot of examples for us to understand what is going on. However, this does not mean that it is good to shove all of them into the slides.

Back onto the professor, I think his presentation of the ideas are good enough and acceptable, the only problem is the pronunciation. Two remarkable examples are Prof. Wang pronounced 'energy' as 'enage' and 'Air pollution' as 'L pollution'. Understandable, but imperfect.
(I have to stress that this course is about *Energy*. Therefore it is surprised for me that he made the pronunciation of these key terms wrong)
reviews.comment_grading:
Course grade percentages are as follows:
Midterm: 40%
Final Exam: 55%
PRS Quizzes: 5% (Only quizzes after the add-drop period counts)

It is strongly recommended to attend all lectures and answer the PRS quizzes, as the PRS questions are mostly easy.
(You can always leave after answering the PRS lol)
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light if you have a broad Physics background and a good memory.
However, if you are not good at Physics, you may want to do more work on it, and resort to cheat sheets for the theories (if allowed in exams).

reviews.comment_teaching: You don't really need to pay attention in class just put everything on the cheat sheet and you will be good
reviews.comment_grading:
45%: Mid Terms
55% Final Exam
5%: PRS

PRS is a bonus so try to attend classes. The mean is pretty high so you need all the marks you can get
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework
No assignments
No quizzes

Just attend classes for PRS

reviews.author: Fabio
reviews.title: An easy course for those who studied physics before
reviews.comment_content: If you are not good or not interested at physics during secondary school, i strongly disagree you to take this course. This course mainly revolve around electromagnetic, environmental friendly, and some history about physics. And there are some knowledge that you might not touch on secondary school like aerodynamic stuffs, the course will talk about it deeply.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since the midterm and final are just things that shown on the powerpoint, thus we don't really need to listen to the prof.. And the lecture is quite boring, and usually it is impossible to follow the pace of the professor unless you have studied those content before.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fine
IPRS will be taken every lecture
Mid term 45%
Final 50%
attendance 5%
I got a B+ by getting above one sd on midterm but just on mean at final
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is light, no homework, no project, just one midterm final and iprs

reviews.author: diego0316
reviews.comment_content: 能源環境野唔使上堂,記得問人攞cheat sheet,攞完就自己寫多啲落cheat sheet 考試mc會考cheat sheet野lq會考啲基本Phy 式但你多數都唔記得,上堂會用iprs ,最好就同fd一齊上,唔係就冇iprs 分, iprs果度都10%,係一個大grade分
reviews.comment_teaching: 冇上過堂
reviews.comment_grading: 考之前溫一兩日就得
reviews.comment_workload: 冇咩功課做

reviews.author: Davon
reviews.comment_content:
too much content
content on the environment issue, power and energy
mainly focus on cheat sheet
have ppt but you will realise it is no use when you copy whole ppt to your cheat sheet
mostly on calculations
reviews.comment_teaching:
boring
have iprs every lesson before dismissal
you can come right before the lesson ends
reviews.comment_grading:
fair grading
many people can get high grades in this course
midterm:
1cheat sheet (2pages)
final:
2cheat sheets (4pages)
both exams are in mc questions and some long questions
reviews.comment_workload:
optional homeworks
can copy some homework question to cheatsheet for reference
all calculations questions

reviews.author: CocoY
reviews.comment_content: A part of content is similar to HKDSE Physics syllabub, especially the elective 'Energy'.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is quite boring but a good grade teacher
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not bad comparing to other courses.
If you can get 1.5SD or above in overall scores, A+ can be got.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course is pretty small. A lot of content can be copy onto the cheat sheet and there is only a little calculus.
If you have the source of cheat sheet and done some past paper before the examination, it is not difficult to get B-range.

reviews.author: Amo晴天
reviews.comment_content: I have to say that the content is not difficult but boring, all the reason why i insist to take class was for IPRS. All the content will be covered in PPT, so textbook is not needed. Basically the topics are about energy: wind, heat, electricity... There will be some important concepts and formula, which is hard to memorize, but you are allowed to put them in your cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is not attractive, they just read the ppt  and maybe show one or two videos per class. So all the revision work should be done by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good, which means it is relatively easier to get into A range, but still quite hard to get A+, you need to do really well in both midterm and final to get A plus. IPRS only counts 5% of final grade, midterm and final is much more important, especially final.
reviews.comment_workload: workload is relatively light. As long as you know what they are teaching, you won't get loss. there is no homework required, they will provide some calculation questions as homework, but homework will not be graded. So you just need to spend one or two weeks to prepare cheat sheet for midterm and final.

reviews.author: Johnlau
reviews.title: RUBBISH PROF WITH HIS OUTSYL EXAM
reviews.comment_content: JUST SOME NORMAL THING ! If you take Energy elective in DSE , it will help you a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: WONG Kam Sing do non of any preparation for lesson. I think he even does not know what he was teaching at that time.Why he can be professors? My Secondary teacher are better than him at least he knows what he was teaching
reviews.comment_grading:
Although Final is very difficult, I only got mean but still having a B.

IPRS:5% Bonus
Mid Term:45%
Final:55%
reviews.comment_workload: NO WORKLOAD. Only IPRS in lessons. It is good for busy students as common core

reviews.author: PoisonNoMajorJJ
reviews.title: Fair SSC-S&T Course
reviews.comment_content:
The content of the course is very VERY scattered.
There is little relationship between each chapter, and you may find it difficult to memorise some less-important things.
It is better if you took HKDSE physics Elective 3.
The content is a bit too many - just a bit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very boring, no matter the content itself or the teacher.
People just arrive at the last minute for the iprs attendance.
I slept in most of the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good.
Midterm: Mean +0.5 SD
Final: Mean +1.5 SD
Attendance: 2 lessons missed
Final grade: A-
The grade is good enough for a year 1 student studying this course - as there are many senior students in science major competing with you.
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework.
Just one midterm, one final, and attendance each lessons.
But you may need some time to practice and revise the contents.
You may also want to spend more time to deal with the cheatsheet.
Luckily the final exam was not accumulative.
But it is very important to spend time on the cheatsheet as it really helps a lot. AND, finish the practice questions made by the professor. They do help.

reviews.author: hlh
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures of the course:
01. Introduction to the course
02. Energy consumption and population growth
03. Fossil fuels
04. Temperature and heat
05. Thermodynamics of heat engines I
06. Thermodynamics of heat engines II
07. Otto engine and passenger cars
08. Diesel engine and cargo ships
09. Jet engine and air travel
10. Midterm exam review
11. Electricity generation
12. Electricity distribution and power grid
13. Electric lighting
14. Energy storage and Home heating cooling
15. Embodied energy

17. Nuclear energy II
18. Water energy

reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is bored as the professor just read aloud the content of the powerpoint in a monotonous way. There are demonstrating during lecture for making it more interesting, but still so boring. I just attend the first few lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading of the course:
Midterm Exam 40%
Final Exam 55%
iPRS Questions 5%
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. No homework.The only workload is that you need to prepare cheatsheet. Just make sure that you have copy all the useful facts and formula in the cheatsheet. Also you need to attend the lectures for the iPRS questions. All the iPRS questions were asked at the end of a lecture, so you can save many time if you only attend the last 10 minutes of the lectures.

reviews.author: ychb
reviews.comment_content: The content is mostly related to energy and numerical figures. The aim of this course is to able to figure out how to calculate energy/power/cost. A certain extent of the content is DSE energy-related stuff. In conclusion, the course is quite rubbish to me
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Cheung just recites almost everything from the slides and his English... really sucks. The way he teaches can hypnotize students. However, he is still a prof who has the heart to teach. As he would organize Q & A sessions before exams for ppl to clarify their concepts about the slides and homework, and the TAs would record the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good in fact, since both my scores in midterm and final are slightly below mean, I still got a B (For the iPRS, I only lost 0.5 marks). I think getting such a grade is due to the fact that I am not so good at Physics. (Since I only got lv. 3 in HKDSE Physics while I am an engineering student... so ashamed...)

The grade of the course is constituted from 5% iPRS, 40% midterm, and 55% final. Both exams allowed cheatsheets. My suggestion for the cheatsheets is that you should try your best to plug all slides into the cheatsheets, lol!
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly nothing, only self-practice, and the goddamn iPRS. Some of the questions in the self-practice are quite retarded because most students don't really get what the questions are asking ppl about, and lack of examples as well as resources result in a drawback to students' familiarity to the course's content. The iPRS are mostly easy questions that you would know the answer without attending the lectures, so some ppl suggest that you just need to enter the venue of the lecture in the last 10-20 mins just for the iPRS. Then you study on your own for the slides.

reviews.comment_content:
