reviews.comment_teaching:
Read from powerpoint at most of the time.
English is okay, with some strange pronunciation for words like "Gadgets", "Mercury"
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 4.6/5 (got 1 question wrong and missed a lecture)
You will get 0 mark for no answer, 0.5 for wrong answer, 1.0 for correct answer.

Midterm (40%): 104/120
(A4 cheatsheet*1)

Final (55%) : 247/260
(A4 cheatsheet *2)
Not cumulative.

Overall : A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Light.

You need to answer the iPrs questions to get the attendance points, so either attend the lectures or ask your friend to give you the code.

You wont really need to do revision for midterm and final because you can bring in cheatsheets into the exam venue. Just make sure that you have included all useful facts and formulae in the cheatsheet.

reviews.author: grateful grade
reviews.title: Energy and Related Environmental Issues
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces the basic concepts of the physical principles behind energy. Various forms of energy and their use (including electricity, fossil energy, nuclear power, various forms of renewable energy), and their impacts on the environment both from a global and regional perspective will be discussed. Issues related to energy conservation and related environmental issues in Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta (PRD) will be discussed.
Lectures of the course:
01. Introduction to the course
02. Energy consumption and population growth
03. Fossil fuels
04. Temperature and heat
05. Thermodynamics of heat engines I
06. Thermodynamics of heat engines II
07. Otto engine and passenger cars
08. Diesel engine and cargo ships
09. Jet engine and air travel
10. Midterm exam review
11. Electricity generation
12. Electricity distribution and power grid
13. Electric lighting
14. Energy storage and Home heating cooling
15. Embodied energy
16. Nuclear energy I
17. Nuclear energy II
18. Water energy
19. Wind energy
20. Solar power
21. Air pollution
22. Global warming and climate change
reviews.comment_teaching: I attended the first few lectures, but they are super boring as the prof speaks in a monotonous way, and so I didn't attend anymore
reviews.comment_grading:
5% IPRS
40% midterm exam
55% Final exam

me:
IPRS: 13/17 since I always got wrong and even missed two of them
Midterm exam: 97/120 (Mean: 77.3, sd: 20.79, above 0.95sd)
Final exam: 223/260 (Mean: 176 after adding mark, sd: 33.39, above 1.4sd)

Final Grade : A
reviews.comment_workload:
0 workload, only iprs
Just show up in the lecture hall in the last 15 mins of the lect for the IPRS, and copy others' answers. Can get 0.5 even if u get it wrong

reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.comment_content:
The course follows the textbook Sustainable Energy Without the Hot Air by David MacKay. Topics covered include:

1. Fossil Fuels
2. Basic Thermodynamics and Electromagnetism
3. Renewable and non-renewable Sources of Energy
4. Environmental Problems associated with the Use of Energy

The content is poorly organised that you can basically treat every lecture as discussing a separate topic without any coherence.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is poor. The professor simply read aloud the content of the powerpoint.

There are demonstrations during lectures, making it slightly more interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme for this course is as follow:

Midterm Exam 40%
Final Exam 55%
PRS Questions 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of the course is light.

The only workload of this course is to attend the lectures for the PRS questions and making the cheat sheet. There is totally no need to work on homework problems and do revision during the semester. For this semester, all the PRS questions were asked at the end of a lecture, so only attending the last 10 minutes of the lectures can save you even more time.

reviews.author: acc_01234
reviews.comment_content: Completely uninteresting content accompanied by a textbook which is not worth reading. Recommended to have strong physics background as the exams contain many physics concepts which are not taught in the lectures. Different lecture notes have different data for the same quantity.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor stutters (and sometimes even pauses) for more than 10 seconds very frequently. No attempts are made to pique interest in students who are taking the course. More than half the class is sleeping in the beginning of the lecture (9AM lecture), only to wake up for the PRS at the end of the class.
reviews.comment_grading: Negative grading for multiple choice questions. 5 marks for correct answer, -1 mark for each wrong answer. Disproportionate marks allocated for long answer questions, e.g. 20 marks for 5 lines of working.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no assignments that has to be submitted. However, there is optional "homework" posted on Canvas which covers a few lectures at a time. The solutions are usually posted a week after the homework has been posted. The solution sometimes uses a different equation to the one in the lecture notes, and is very inconsistent with significant figures.

reviews.author: tcwong
reviews.title: A very broad course with nice grading
reviews.comment_content:
Covers a very wide range of materials related energy&environment, Inter Alia:
-energy consumption&population growth
-fossil fuels
-thermodynamics&engines
-transport (energy loss/energy required)
-energy distribution
-lighting
-home heating&cooling
-embodied energy
-energy generation (nuclear/water/wind/solar)
-air pollution
-global warming

The content is interesting but very broad, it covers topics from Liberal Studies, Physics (up to PHYS1112 level), and Chemistry, so it's beneficial if you are familiar with these fields. (Personally, as a chemical engineering major, I found these materials highly related to what I'm studying.)
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturer is quite enthusiastic, however, the lecture notes are not easy to follow, and usually includes a lot of data that may be boring. Supplementary self-learning is suggested.
reviews.comment_grading:
A good grade School-Sponsored course if you have a strong background in the sciences.

Marking Scheme:
45% midterm (with cheat sheet)
55% final (with cheat sheet)
5%  Bonus iPRS (100% for correct, 50% for wrong, 0% for not answering)

My Score:
Mid-term: 194/200 mean:142.2 sd:25.2
Final: 363/400 mean:254 sd:63
iPRS: 20/21

Overall: 98.3% (including iPRS)
Grade:A+

But don't be intimidated, the A range is very broad, and the requirement for A+ is a lot more manageable than it may seem.
reviews.comment_workload: Basically no workload, you only have to do the optional iPRS (although highly recommended) every lesson, and prepare for the cheat sheets. (And self-studying if you plan on getting a decent grade)

reviews.author: wppsteve
reviews.comment_content:
Not all the topics are not related to the energy, like the magnetic, the aerospace etc.
You may think the course required you to do many calculation, but also you have to spend many times to memorize the theory, the process of the energy operation and the data etc...
reviews.comment_teaching: only repeat the ppt shown in the lecture, the sound is quite boring.
reviews.comment_grading: someone said this course is a quite good grading course. Undoubtedly they may true. If you can spend many time in this course of memorizing the notes and attend all (or most of the) lesson to get as many bonus point as you can.
reviews.comment_workload:
no homework are disturbed, but the IPRS section required you to attend all lesson in order to get the bonus marks.
In both mid-term and final exam, only one A4 (two-sides) cheat sheet can be brought in the exam venue. So i strongly suggest you to write down the formula in the cheat sheets and memorize the theory into your mind.

reviews.author: Zechidlin
reviews.comment_content: Almost nothing to do with physics.Just with a few simple formulae that you’ve already learnt in high school. To be honest,the content of this course—if provided in a more in-depth version can be much better. While the course director choose to try covering every aspect of energy and ‘related issues’ instead of focusing on several important topics,say,thermodynamics. Too many statistics in slides that nobody cares, but they may appear in exams! If you want to take SSC course, this will be the best one—all contents can be learned without attending classes(if you attend you will find the only meaningful thing is to take prs for 5 bonus points).
reviews.comment_teaching: Mediocre. The instructor’s accent is quite heavy but he has tried to explain everything slowly and clearly. Listening to him can make you feel sleepy,along with the embarrassing course material...sometimes it’s better to do sth else in class.Though, the instructor is still kind and willing to answer questions if you have any.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very good. midterm counts for 45%, final 55%,with a bonus of 5% in form of prs that are very easy.The rule for scoring in exam is weird. Marks will be deducted if you select the wrong answer in MCs, and you will get 0 if the final answer of the problem is wrong. However, short problems are easy to deal with, just MCs..really annoying. Everything in slides may appear in exams especially MCs,but you can make cheat sheet, which makes it easier for handling the exams.

midterm mean:142.2, sd:25.2
final mean:254,sd:63
my grade:177/200,350/400,prs almost full mark.
Turns out to be A+.
Hence the grading is very,very good.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. Only some problem sets that are used for reviewing, no need to hand in.

reviews.author: momo1234
reviews.comment_content: The course is about physics about the environment. The first part is mainly about thermodynamics and different kinds of engines. Then you will have the midterm. After the midterm you will have electricity, including different kinds of renewable energies. Although it is called a physics class, I don't think that the maths are difficult for this course. I personally think it is more about memorization (and remember to include some important graphs in the lecture notes the cheat sheet!)
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has HORRIBLE English accent. I stopped going to class because of hid accent because I knew that i can never concentrate with his accent.
reviews.comment_grading:
Take attendance with iPRS, they will ask you a MC question with iPRS and you can get points with it. Answering correctly will give you 1 mark and if you answered the wrong answer they will only give you 0.5 marks.
The grading is quite nice. I got below 1.5 SD in midterm and 1SD in final, and only got 1 mark for attendance and ended up with a C+.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload, only have midterm and final exam (both you can bring a cheat sheet in). They will provide you with exercise for you to work with but it is optional.

reviews.author: HugoNFT
reviews.title: Good grades
reviews.comment_content: Can be easy or difficult to understand depending on the topic, but flat-out bad teaching doesn't help. Topics are also scattered and manifold. Better off relying on cheatsheets and own prior knowledge honestly.
reviews.comment_teaching: Can't say it's good, even if you concentrate you wouldn't catch much. Lessons are quite boring and mostly attended due to PRS. Powerpoints are read out and they don't even teach much. Pratically non-existent interaction.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty good grades, considering I was below a SD for the midterm and was close to the mean score in the finals and still got a B-. In other courses this would totally net us a C-range. Still, the mean is frankly ridiculously high and you will have to compete against higher year students possibly if you're a year 1 student.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload whatsoever. Revision may or may not be needed either. An A4-sized cheat sheet can be used in both exams. Only that you are kind of penalized for skipping lessons as each contains a PRS question and it plays a very minor part in your final results.

reviews.author: Peter Wat
reviews.comment_content:
About energy.

Content is a bit too much: fossil fuels, thermodynamics, heat engines, transport, electricity, nuclear energy, water energy, wind energy, solar energy, air pollution, global warming.

Can't find the focus of the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Boring.

Most of the time is reading powerpoint.
Instructor can't explain some complicated idea so clearly.

Some lectures involve demonstrations but they are just not so interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% prs (bonus)
100% mid-term + final

One cheat sheet is allowed for both mid-term and final.

Both mid-term and final above mean, finally got an A-
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework needs to be handed in.

Homework is uploaded just for self revision.

reviews.author: AJLP
reviews.title: Recommended for patient students who like numbers
reviews.comment_content: Crappy. Ugly. Badly-designed. You could check the syllabus in other reviews, but I tell you - being interested in the topics will not save you from how boring this class is! The presentations will have about 30-50 slides each lecture wherein only 2-5 slides are actually useful for the exams. There might be demos, but they're not helpful, not even that fun to watch!
reviews.comment_teaching: The English of the professors are heavily accented. I had a hard time maintaining my focus because it was so tiring to process what they were saying. They kept reading the presentations and it was extremely boring. Reading on your own would save you a lot of time, but you need to attend lectures if you want the bonus points.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty lenient?

45% Midterms
55% Finals
5% iPRS Bonus

I don't think the iPRS Bonus matters a lot as long as you get more than half of the points. It's just a bonus, anyways.

The exams in this course have two parts: MCQ and Short Answer. The MCQs can be handled by a good cheatsheet, so just prepare for that. The Short Answer requires numerical skills. Funny enough, you don't need to understand the physics if you have the formulas. Sometimes, the Short Answer is similar to the ungraded homework, but only sometimes. The extra reading materials are useless.
reviews.comment_workload: There is virtually no concrete workload, except for the cheatsheet. Because this class is so boring, I would recommend it only to those who think they could survive the numbers and the boring environment. If you think you're slightly impatient, do yourself a favor and take something else!

reviews.author: Edmond Chan
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course is similar to some MECH and PHYS course. (Heat transfer, renewable energy and embodied energy) It is meaningless to attend lectures. Have to pay attention to those video link in the ppt.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructors speaks poor English.
There are lots of statistics given during lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% for iPRS
The final included "quite difficult" long questions.
Some content asked in final is not taught during lectures. The final was somehow confusing.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is no assignment.
Only midterm and final for this course
HW are optional.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm exam scope:
1. Introduction
2. Energy consumption & Population growth
3. Fossil fuels
4. Temperature & Heat
5~6. Thermodynamics of heat engines
7. Otto engine & Passenger cars
8. Diesel engine & Cargo ships
9. Jet engine & Air travel

Final exam scope:
11. Electricity generation
12. Electricity power grid
13. Electric lighting
14. Energy storage & Home heating
15. Embodied energy in stuff
16~17. Nuclear energy
18. Water energy
19. Wind energy
20. Solar energy
21. Air pollution
22. Global warming & Climate change

As you can see, every lesson you learn another topic. For those who does not want an in-depth understanding of particular field(s) or topic(s), you may enrol this course. For me, I just wanted to fulfil the SSC-S&T requirement.

In both exams, you may carry one A4 cheat sheet written or printed on either or both sides. There were MC questions about data, so you may want to include some of the important data in your cheat sheet.


In my opinion, just prepare whatever you can before exams as questions in the exam papers were not similar to those in the optional worksheets. Some even did not appears on the worksheets, yet the knowledge and question situation should have been talked about during the lectures.

It is suggested you have some basic knowledge in physics, like having taken physics in your high school. Also, some topics are just common with MECH1906 Contemporary Living
reviews.comment_teaching:
I found her voice too boring to hear. My section started at 9 and always do I felt asleep during the lecture. In the end, I just skipped the class and found someone to helped me with the PRS quiz. Plus, sometimes I found hard to understand what she was talking about owing to her ascent (she is from the mainland China).

There were lecture videos, but I prefer reading the lecture slides by myself. Make sure you can read the graphs in the lecture slides and obtain data from them accurately as some of them appeared in the exam, identically.
reviews.comment_grading:
Item, weights, score, full mark, mean, sd:

Midterm, 45%, 175, 200, 142.2, 25.2
Final, 55%, 277, 400, 254.2, 63
PRS (bonus), 5%, 12.5, 15, 11.4(it is just an estimation based on the mean of individual PRS quiz, with mode 0.7), (sd unknown)
Grade A-
Note: PRS: correct - full mark ; incorrect - half mark ; no answer - 0 mark. PRS during add/drop period was not counted.
reviews.comment_workload:
No compulsory assignments.
You may find pretty busy one week before exam as you need to prepare the cheat sheet.

reviews.author: Trollolol
reviews.title: Fall sem唔好讀
reviews.comment_content:
Energy咩都有D
Fuels, Thermodynamics, Engines, Electricity, Renewable energy

如果唔係midterm對thermodynamics一無所知 會讀得好辛苦

考試考好多單位傳換
老老竇竇 個course對實際知識吸收無咩用
只係攞黎滿足cc requirement

三個professor都黎過講書 (因為本身個professor有一排出左去帶trip)
三個都好差
powerpoint照讀 英文又差
有次professor解錯PRS 講錯答案 不過本身都無人聽書
最衰有PRS無得走堂
reviews.comment_grading:

Midterm: 137/200    (Mean: 142.2   SD = 25.2)
Final: 305/400    (Mean: 254    SD = 63)

最後好彩B+
reviews.comment_workload:
因為傻傻地係Year 1 first term讀  Midterm前既內容一D都聽唔明
讀得好辛苦 溫書溫好耐
不過如果你後期D讀 有physics底 應該幾輕鬆

係要花時間溫書+整cheat sheet

reviews.author: #001/BULBASAUR
reviews.title: Pointless course, decent grading
reviews.comment_content:
The content of the course should not be a factor when considering whether or not to enroll in this course. Learning from the lectures or slideshows is almost impossible due to the extremely unorganized content and the inclusion of many irrelevant data. If you really wish to learn more about energy and related environmental issues, I suggest you pay Wikipedia a visit - that would be more worth-while.

The scopes for the mid-term and final examinations are unimportant. The answers for the majority of the paper can be deduced from simple arithmetic or found on a well-made cheatsheet. Just copy everything you find useful (or bizarre), such as equations, oddly specific numerical values, graphs, onto your cheatsheet and you will be good to go.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Atrocious. The lecturer is blatantly incompetent for the level of education he had attained. Mr. Wong speaks in an unbearably broken accent which makes parsing his sentences impossible. To give you an idea on how broken his spoken English is, he pronounced "ship" as "shit".

He also reads the slideshows word-by-word. Unfortunately, provided that the slideshows are messy and irrelevant, his text-to-speech would not help you understand the content any better. For instance, when giving a lecture on thermodynamics, he provided us a certain equation without explaining what any of the variables means.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Examination: 45%
Final Examination: 55%
PRS Quizzes: 5% bonus

Overall Score: 88.39/100 (+~4.76 bonus marks)
Letter Grade: A+

For a SSC, this common core course has a reasonably attainable A range. If you do not mind wasting your time on such a meaningless course, I would recommend this course to you for the sake of good grade.

This course is also decent for securing you a satisfactory B or B+ if you manage to score around mean for this course, which should not be difficult since most of the exam questions require little to no brain effort.
reviews.comment_workload: Your only workload would be PRS and revising for the examinations. Optional, ungraded homework is available for you to practise for the assessment, and they are certainly useful in my opinion. If you desire extra safety measure, remember to attend or lectures (or get your friends to attend the lectures for you) for the bonus PRS points.

This course will introduce the basic concepts of the physical principles behind energy. Various forms of energy and their use (including electricity, fossil energy, nuclear power, various forms of renewable energy), and their impacts on the environment both from a global and a regional perspectives will be discussed. reviews.author: Justin Li
reviews.title: Not very Physics course that requires good Physics knowledge
reviews.comment_content: The entire course focuses on energy, from thermodynamics, different types of engines all the way to renewable energy and pollution. The course focuses the use of physics calculations towards energy issues, so you must have quite good physics concepts as they don't teach them (expecting you to know them).
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor focuses a lot on statistical data and case studies, which will not appear in exams. His English is also rather hard to understand and he often reads from the powerpoint, so not very useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
45% from mid-term, 55% from final, additional 5% from PRS. Mean for both mid-term and final are around 60%, even though the final is more difficult than mid-term.
Also, both mid-term and final contains multiple choice questions that gives 5 marks per correct answer and deduct 1 mark per incorrect one, which is quite significant considering the large number of MCQs.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is low along most days as there are no hand-in work involved. PRS will be conducted every lecture (which is the attendance record). Cheat-sheet is allowed in exam so that requires some work. There are homework that does not need to be handed in, but useful for exam preparation.

if you want a higher mark, you will need to go for the lessons and do the iPRS questions

reviews.author: skwat
reviews.title: it's all about cheat sheet
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures with the following topics and sequence:
Starts from energy, and ends with environmental impacts.
L1:      Introduction to the course and Population Growth
L2:       Energy generation, use and consumption
L3:       Fossil Fuels I
L4:       Fossil Fuels II
L5:       Thermodynamics of Heat Engine I
L6:       Thermodynamics of Heat Engine II
L7:       Otto engine, passenger car, electric car
L8:       Diesel engine and cargo ships
L9:       Air travel and jet engine
L10:     Electricity and its generation;
L11:      Step-up and step-down transformers; Electric power grid;
L12:      Batteries, fuel cells and energy for Home Heating and Cooling
L13:     Electric lighting
L14:     Embodied energy in “Stuff”; RPUD four phases; Food and farming; E-waste.
L15:     Nuclear energy I
L16:      Nuclear energy II
L17:     Water Power
L18:     Wind Power
L19:     Solar Power    
L20:     Air pollution
L21:     Global warming
L22:     Climate change

Indeed, the last few topics are quite boring.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor's teaching is clear but it's quite boring as he speaks slowly. However, I don't think there is any difference between reading the materials on your own and attending the lecture in terms of materials understanding......as long as you have some phys background (energy, nuclear decay, electricity...).
Still, there is a reason that you should attend the lecture: the grading.
reviews.comment_grading:
40%  Midterm Exam (cheat sheet allowed)
55%  Final Exam (again, cheat sheet allowed)
5%  PRS quizzes (during lecture, most likely at the end of each topic)

It's all about cheat sheet, that's all I would like to say. Make sure you put all useful formulas or else you would mess up long questions. PRS only counts for the best 70% score as there were problems on the Wi-Fi reception during some lectures...
reviews.comment_workload: The are problem sets for your own practice. Other than that, it's nearly no workload required.

reviews.author: Annie Shek
reviews.comment_content:
認真我淨係讀hw
冇點睇過PPT
Content都幾雜下
不過DSE有讀E3都會明因為大概都係E3啲野
reviews.comment_teaching:
上過lecture一兩次
完全聽唔明prof講咩
上親堂都係成班人自己做自己野等prs
reviews.comment_grading:
幾靚grade呀
midterm & final above mean 半個sd都B+左
45%midterm 55%final + 5% extra prs
reviews.comment_workload:
midterm final溫書就得
零workload
想a range就去埋lecture攞prs

reviews.author: Annika_wyt
reviews.comment_content:
A bit boring, the main content is basic facts, easy to understand, except the chapter on thermodynamics,
If you have studied DSE level physics with elective chapter on energy, it will be easier for you to remember some of the content
reviews.comment_teaching: Very boring, some professors spoke monotone, can't even concentrate. Also, the majority of them only read according to the powerpoint, so, you actually can read it yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: quite good, an A4 size cheat sheet is allowed during the exam, if you know what are the main ideas of each chapter, it will be easy.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework, only midterm and final exam

reviews.author: 兆康
reviews.comment_content:
It is said that the content is not related to physics. And it is true. Seriously, you don't need any physics knowledge. Here is the topics:
01. Introduction to the course
02. Energy consumption & population growth
03. Fossil fuels
04. Temperature, heat and heat energy
05. Thermodynamics
06. Heat engine
07. Otto engine and passenger cars
08. Diesel engine and cargo ships
09. Jet engine and air travel
10. Midterm exam review
11. Electricity generation
12. Electricity power grid
13. Electric lighting
14. Energy storage and home heating cooling
15. Embodied energy in stuff
16. Nuclear energy I
17. Nuclear energy II
18. Water energy
19. Wind energy
20. Solar energy
21. Air pollution
22. Global warming and climate change
23. Final exam review
reviews.comment_teaching: You may not understand the content because of their poor English. Sometimes they carry out some experiments, but you are just allowed to see it, but not to do it. Unless you sit in the front, you will not be able to see it clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Some says it is easy to get A. Some says it is rubbish.
Have midterm and final.
You are allowed to bring one A4-size (two sides) cheat sheet.
Two types of questions: MC and LQ.
My midterm covers 01-09, final covers 11-22.
Every lessons have PRS, maybe before lessons or after lessons. PRS questions counts 5% towards the final grade. You get 1 marks for correct answer, 0.5 marks for wrong answer, no mark for no answer.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework. Only four homework for self-learning, they will give you the answer a few lessons later.

reviews.author: NE555
reviews.comment_content:
Course content was mildly interesting at best, boring and irrelevant at worst, which unfortunately is the case most of the time.
They do make an effort to cover a wide range of topics that were somewhat related to energy. Hopefully that wide range was the only reason the course instructors struggle to answer student's question adequately during lectures.
The topics and questions examined in this course weren't exactly hard, but just randomly put together without much thought.
The HW and exam mostly consists of trivial arithmetic questions with technical terms stuck into it, challenging your understanding of the term "Physics exam". There was also cartoon, low res graphs where precise numbers had to be derived for accurate calculations. Did I also mention the occasional exam question that involves physics topics never mentioned once in all lectures and homework? Did they even look at the exam paper once before printing it?
reviews.comment_teaching: Couldn't understand what was coming out from the instructor's mouth most of the time. Fortunately they scraped the majority of the course contents from the internet so you can find the source yourself and study from there. If you don't understand anything from this course, just go to youtube. Have yet found a youtube video that explains the course topics worse than the lecturers. Though that begs the question: Why am I paying tuition fees?
reviews.comment_grading: PRS during lectures does count towards final grade, though giving up the lectures for more sleep (totally worth it) did not seem to affect my grades much. Course does not contain any content that requires more than half a brain to process, so just cram useful lecture slides into your cheat sheet and you should score well in both exams. I have no idea how I got an A for this course, but I won't complain.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework was optional and not counted towards course grade. Though the HW does make good exam practice questions.
If you previously took the energy elective for HKDSE Physics, then most ideas presented in the course won't be new to you.
In other words you don't really have to do anything for this course, other than optionally show up for lecture PRS.

reviews.author: csisgood
reviews.title: The most rubbush course I have even taken
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course are totally rubbish . You will learn nothing from this course . So many fucking historical statistic and data. Some content involve calculation and formula but without or lack of explanation.PowerPoint Just have some formula and so many unknown variable.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The worst lectures I ever taken in HKUST.
Three professor just read through the powerpoint.
No extra content.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is not bad. Since teaching is so fucking poor , most of the students don't know what was this course talking about.So if you are good at self-learning , you will get a good grade in this course .
reviews.comment_workload: No workload . But you need to attend ALL!!! 24 fucking boring lecture since you need to answer the questions through PRS System at the end of lecture.This part also count marks.

reviews.author: Davidliu
reviews.title: PHYS1003
reviews.comment_content:
Knowledge about environment, simply calculation
Related to physic
reviews.comment_teaching:
Different lecturers responsible for different aspects of the lecture
Quite boring normally, but sometimes have experiments can be demonstrated.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade if you pay attention in class and pay little effort to review before the examination.
The examination is easy because you can bring your own cheat sheet.
you can pass the examination and get C grade easily if your cheat sheet is reliable enough, even though you do not listen to the lecture.
reviews.comment_workload:
this course has no homework, you only need to take attendance.
The workload is absolute zero unless you want to get A grade.

reviews.author: Binayg
reviews.title: Not as easy as you think
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly about sustainable energy,
Aeroplanes, fossil fuels and renewable energy
reviews.comment_teaching: The professors have very monotoned voice and will be very difficult to listen to especially early in the morning. Strongly recommend you not to take 9am lectures of this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Decent grading.

45% of the course grading on mid term
55% of the course grading on final exam
5% bonus on IPRS if you get all correct on the questions they ask in class

Mid-term: 137/200      Mean : 148/200
Final exam: 246/400   Mean: 254.7/400
IPRS-> Free 5% bonus

Final Grade: B
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload but there are homework for self-revision and will help you but some of the answers are questionable.

reviews.author: sam339
reviews.title: Good Grade
reviews.comment_content: It includes basic knowledge concerning the environment as well as the use of energy. Many of them are DSE physics related, in the elective of energy. If you have studied for it before, it will be easy to understand the related part. The part concerning environment includes some common sense as well, which is quite easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is quite boring as some of them are the same as the physics in DSE and some others can be easily understood by common sense. It is repetitive to listen to the content.
reviews.comment_grading: Cheet sheet is allowed and this it is not quite difficult to get a good mark as long as you have fully understood what the content means.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment.
Just 5% IPRS, mid-term and final.

reviews.author: Perna Wong
reviews.title: I have 0 background in Physics
reviews.comment_content: For the mid-term exam part, most of them are about engines (diesel, ,jet, auto). As I am not a student with Physics background, this course is the most difficult course that I have taken till now. For the final exam part, most of them are about energy and calculations like how much energy is consumed and how much do we need to pay for electricity supply. At the beginning, I thought it would be better after the engine part. However, the energy part is not easy to understand. For me, I must write the formulas on the cheat sheet. If you are a Physics student, you must think that it is very easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is the most boring part. I always feel tired in the lessons. And their English is not understandable. But you have to pay attention to the lesson because of the iprs session! You cannot skip lessons if you want to get 5% of your course marks. (5% is important to me because I am not a smart student)
reviews.comment_grading:
Don't mention the exam again. The final exam is so messily designed. I feel very dizzy while doing it because there are too many numbers and units like per person per year per month per day etc. The professors asked us to do homework and I did it, but it didn't help much in the exam. Many contents are not taught deeply in the lessons.

Back to the grading, I am very satisfied with my grade. I am below the mean like 0.5-1 SD for both mid-term and final exam, but I still got B- at last (I thought I would get C- or D!). Maybe it is because of the large number of students (400 or more?). So if you are at mean, you will get B or B+.

If you are concerned about your exam marks, the course will set up the paper checking sessions after the exam so that you can know your actual marks and the wrong answers. It's good for all the students.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is the only thing that I am happy about. No official homework. No project. No quiz. Just iprs (5% only), mid-term and final exam! The homework is for your own study, but most of the answers are released right before the exams... Sometimes, the answers are mistaken too!

reviews.author: Walhalancs
reviews.comment_content:
Basically everything about energy and environment. It will be a good grade common core if you take PHYS1112, or have taken physics course before. If you don't, you can still understand a bunch of stuff about environ, like global warming, pollution, recycling, etc.

To be honest, I don't know what I have learned after the courses. If you go for a Good-Graded Common Core, go for it. If you want to bring something useful or innovative, then you should not choose this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
You barely need to be taught on those basic environ stuff,  but you may need an extra attention on thermal dynamics, aerodynamics(just a little)

Teaching is horribly boring, and they teach with their interesting accent. I would prefer an afternoon nap, rather than get up at 9, and sleep there.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is lenient I think, 85% and I get an A

The exam is divided into 2 parts, MC, and Long question. Half of the paper are calculations and the rest is basic knowledge of environ

The full marks for each exam are 200, and if u get lost for 40 marks in each exam, u still end up with 80% mark.....
reviews.comment_workload:
There is no homework, all u need is a well-prepared cheatsheet
You need to do PRS for some of the lessons, that why I CANT SKIP LESSONS !!!But then, you just sleep there...

reviews.author: 仁和
reviews.title: good grade
reviews.comment_content: dull and tedious
reviews.comment_teaching: boring
reviews.comment_grading:
very easy to get A+ as long as you take notes  
平时听课不用太认真吧，当然如果能好好记整理重点期中期末时会轻松很多。考试前看看lecture notes 然后整理一下，cheat sheet 做完整一点，基本大部分题目都有把握。 期末考试比期中考试内容多，期中更简单一些。
reviews.comment_workload: only busy before the exams

reviews.author: CyrusL
reviews.comment_content:
LIST OF TOPICS:
- Energy consumption and population growth
- Fossil fuels
- Thermodynamics
- Heat engines (Otto, diesel, jet)
~~~MIDTERM~~~
- Electricity generation and power grid
- Electric lighting
- Energy storage and home temperature regulation
- Embodied energy
- Nuclear, water, wind and solar energy
- Global warming and climate change
~~~FINAL EXAM~~~

There is an exam review lecture before each exam, which lays out the exact syllabus that may be examined.

Since this course requires HKDSE Physics level 3+, students are already familiar with many of the topics discussed. However, this course enables us to further extend our knowledge to many aspects of the real world, enhancing our understanding of energy generation and consumption.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Wang and Dr. Wong's lectures are extremely boring, and they mostly read off the slides. Combined with the fact that they started at 9 am, I found it extremely difficult to stay awake without using my phone.

The PowerPoints are regularly uploaded to Canvas, you might as well skip the lectures and read the content online if you don't care about PRS marks.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Exam - 45%
Final Exam - 55%
PRS - 5% bonus

The topics covered in the midterm and final exams do not overlap.
A PRS question is asked in each teaching lecture. A correct answer gives full marks, while a wrong answer gives half marks.

My results:
z = 0.71 for midterm
z = 2.25 for final exam
4.71% PRS bonus
94.03%* overall score, landed me in A+.

*Edit: Now inclusive of RPS Bonus
reviews.comment_workload:
There are a few assignments for this course, but they are just for self-revision and do not have to be handed in.

A double-sided A4 cheat sheet is allowed in each exam, so you do not have to memorize much.

This course emphasizes working with numbers, but understanding their underlying concepts is also extremely important for the exams.

reviews.author: Kiddo
reviews.title: VERY BAD
reviews.comment_content: The whole course is NOT about physics, it's just about a bunch of facts and data. A large number of lecture notes is present but no physics knowledge was gained after the semester. Content was horrible.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professors don't really pay much effort in teaching this course, only reading out powerpoints. Not good.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is a better part of the course, since Science students tend to think this is easy for them and students from other faculties tend to think they don't have to pay effort in a common core course, it was easy to score A-range.
reviews.comment_workload: Really nothing to do. There is homework but non-compulsory, the questions there are much harder than exams'. One mid-term, one final, that's it.

reviews.author: Casper
reviews.title: 垃圾course
reviews.comment_content:
課程嘅內容又多又亂。PowerPoint slides 會有好多self-learning materials，而問題係exam會問得好specific (mainly MC)，例如會問比wind turbine 打死嘅雀仔多啲定係比打貓打死嘅雀仔多啲。

Thermodynamics 嗰 part 教得好唔清楚。如果嗰part唔熟嘅話，後面關於engine嘅topic就會好混亂。

好彩exam可以比你用貓紙，所以只要貓紙寫好啲嘅話，exam嘅分應該係一定>50%。但係exam 嘅問題係通常唔straight-forward 同比教少計數，所以好易失分。

Course content (copied from Canvas) （比重大嗰啲）
。Fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas
。Basic energy principles and thermodynamics, including 1st and 2nd law, heat engine efficiency
。Petrol and diesel engines for land and sea transport, gas turbine for air transport
。Electricity generation and motors
。Nuclear power and safety
。Renewable energy resources: water, wind, sunlight
。Impacts of energy use on the environment, emissions & global warming
reviews.comment_teaching:
照ppt 謴，同埋佢地謮嘅方式會令你好想瞓覺

會用iPRS 迫人上堂

冇嘢補充因為我幾乎冇上堂
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam: 45%
Final Exam: 55%
Plus 5% bonus by PRS quizzes

我iPRS 只係take 唨一半，因為我走咗半個course
Exam 嘅分 (mean) / 總分
Midterm: 146 (147.6) / 200
Final: 288 (249.6) / 400

Grade: B ( 74.95% / 100%)
reviews.comment_workload: 冇一定要submit 嘅功課。啲問題都好廢，thermodynamic 以外嗰問題好廢，基本上睇兩眼就ok。冇時間嘅話唔睇都冇問題，因為exam好少會出會出咁淺。兩次exam都只係總出番一條HW入面嘅問題，可見出番嘅頻率好低。

reviews.author: JK1
reviews.title: A Good Grade Common-core but You Can't Learn Anything
reviews.comment_content:
This course basically talk about the thermodynamics, renewable energy and energy related to daily things. The framework of this course is great, but the lecture slides are poorly designed with a lot of useless information and figures, which may make students feel distracted.
1 double-sided A4 cheat sheet is allowed in both mid-term and final exam.
Before Mid-term: Physics-related, mainly about thermodynamics, different types of engines: otto engine, diesel engine, jet engine.
After Mid-term: Topics covered are boarder and most of them are learnt in high school, including electricity, nuclear energy, electric lighting, nuclear energy; and some renewable energy, such as: water, wind, solar, etc. Finally, air pollution and global warming.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly, the course framework is great but the teaching is very bad, especially the lecturers' presentation.
Poor English presentation and the tone of these lecturers are really bad, making you feel boring and distracted.
The lecture notes are filled with figures and useless information with some important key points hidden (you need some time and effort to find it)
The demonstrations done by the TA are the most interesting part in the lecture.
After the course, you may find that you haven't learnt anything new and useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
As a reference, I have got above mean around 1 SD in both mid-term and final exam and got a A. It is quite reasonable as a common-core course.
iPRS is also count towards the grade, don't miss any lesson (or you may ask your friend to help you)
Mid-term (45%); Final exam (55%); iPRS (5%, correct: 1 point; incorrect or technical problems: 0.5 points; no response: 0 points)
reviews.comment_workload:
Basically zero. No homework and assignment. Homework is just for your practice (some may appear in mid-term and final exam, do it before the exam day)
Material covered in mid-term exam will not be asked in final.
Work hard before the exam day (it is enough to get a good grade) and prepare a "useful" cheat sheet.

reviews.author: iwantarange
reviews.title: Very boring, but good grade due to large population
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm: Thermodynamics, engines and other non-related stuffs.
After midterm: Different kinds of renewable energy, with some overlapping with HKDSE physics E3 (Energy and Use of Energy).

As mentioned by the instructors, this is not a physics course, and I have to agree with that. If you are having regular physics learning at HKUST, do not expect to learn some physics knowledge. The course title 'energy and related environmental issues' is the only thing you can learn from this course, which does not look interesting/attractive.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Probably one of the worst teaching ever. While you may hope to have at least an interesting lecture given the fact that there are 3 instructors, the answer is no. Their pronunciations are not very good, and you may not wish to listen to their teaching, especially if you are having this course at 9am. If there is no iPRS counting as extra credits, I wonder if there is anyone going to the lessons. Simply reading the lecture notes is enough as their teaching does not matter a lot in the exams.
Nevertheless, the IA of this course is quite good and he does some good demos during the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Given that this course has a large population since this is a SSC course, the grades seem not too bad if you are competent in physics and have studies E3 in HKDSE physics.
Midterm: above ~1.6SD (45%)
Final: above ~2SD (55%)
iPRS: ~90% (5% extra credits)
Grade: A+
While getting A+ requires some luck (like me), getting A range should be possible if you have made a good cheatsheet and have a solid physics background.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework at all, the only workload is making cheatsheet before midterm and final exam, which you may feel annoyed when doing so.

reviews.author: Dolores
reviews.title: So boring
reviews.comment_content: The content is wide but not so deep. Read the PPT and you can know everything.
reviews.comment_teaching: Really bad. Every time I just want to go to sleep but it has IPRS.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam:                  45%

Final Exam:                        55%

Plus 5% bonus by PRS quizzes



Rules for PRS:

Full Marks for correct answers, half marks for incorrect answers, 0 marks for no answers.
Marks will not be counted during the add-drop period.

So you have to attend to the boring and useless lectures to get your IPRS mark. The midterm exam is not very difficult but some people thought it was not easy. The suggestion is preparing a good cheat sheet and review all the PPTs carefully.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost no workload except for exam periods.

reviews.author: SomeoneInUST2
reviews.title: Not worthy, go and take another CCC
reviews.comment_content: The content is not really related to calculation of physics question but more about remembering different facts of physics. PPTs are provided on canvas. Many printed them out before classes to take notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both are pretty boring. They speak in flat tones.
Btw, the TAs are nice in answering questions :)
reviews.comment_grading:
It greatly depends.
Some of many friends say it is a good grade course while some (as I do ) think it is a bad course.
The content in ppts, homework and exams are pretty different. I think the exams mainly test your maths and calculation abilities. If you have master physics well in high school, then go for it. Otherwise, I suggest you to double consider.
What you put in the cheatsheet is our important!
Noted: we can bring one double-side A4 cheatsheet to both the mid-term and final. Make sure you have put the right content on them.
reviews.comment_workload:
Nearly no workload.
There is PRS in each class so better come to class.
There is some homework too but you can choose to do them or not since the professors never check them. \

reviews.author: Yau Yat Fung
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Physic Concept
Mainly memory thing
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quiet Boring
But still need to go for PRS
reviews.comment_grading:
Below mean nearly 2 SD C+

PRS 5%, Midterm 40%, Final 55%
Unreasonable grading with respect to the effort put in to learning the course content. Although a cheat sheet is allowed in the exams, it is of no use whatsoever. The paper has 2 parts- MC Questions with a ridiculous +5, -1 marking scheme and long answer questions with 10-20 marks awarded for correct answer (depending on question) and none for wrong. The curve comes absolutely ridiculous with 2-3 bell curves and high mean and S.D. that make it hard to assess one's performance.  People usually take Common Cores to bring their grades up, but really cannot expect that with this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Not thing to do

reviews.author: Naomi
reviews.title: Not bad
reviews.comment_content: Some had been taught in secondary school and most of the content are not hard to understand. Even you don't come to lesson, you could also handle the exam
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite detailed but a bit boring
reviews.comment_grading: It is not bad but not as good as people said
reviews.comment_workload: No assignment but have prs every lesson. As cheat sheet is allowed in both midterm and final exam, the workload is relatively small. Midterm and final include mc and short questions. Short questions are similar to the homework. So it is not difficult as long as you have completed the homework

reviews.author: LULLUL
reviews.title: Simple, easy general course
reviews.comment_content: It covers so many topics, from thermodynamics, global warming, renewable energy and so on... Basically it covers so much that there isn't any depth in any of the topics. The content is so shallow that you do not even need any science knowledge to comprehend. So I would say the content is easy, but not all that useful.
reviews.comment_teaching: I only went to the first 5 or so lectures, missed out every single lectures after mid-term. As far as I can tell, the instructor's English is pretty bad, and is terrible at handling computers and related technologies. The PRS does not work for most of the time, partly because the instructor is stupid, and also the TAs. Powerpoint reading for most of the time. Don't expect any quality teaching. No point in attending lectures unless you desperately need the PRS points.
reviews.comment_grading: Skip lectures, cram it 2 or 3 days before exam, bam, A range. Got an A with ~1.2 SD above mean on average for mid-term and final, with less than half of the total PRS marks. Seems good for me. If you are an engineering or science student, definitely easy to achieve.
reviews.comment_workload: Only mid-term and final. Just get someone to do the PRS, no homework, no other bullshit. Just read the goddamn powerpoints, make a cheatsheet, and you are done with the course. Least workload course I ever had.

reviews.author: Roddie
reviews.title: TONS OF STUFF TO REMEMBER AND UNDERSTAND
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm is about how various types of engines work and how the work is done. Also talk about fossil fuel and plane. In this part, the most difficult part is how the engines work and the PV diagram.
After midterm is about various of energy, like solar power, wind power, hydropower, nuclear power and so on.
in total 22 lecture slides and all packed with information and knowledge, you need to absorb.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Even when I attend the class I do not pay much attention since he basically just reading the slides.
But he is very responsible, every time you ask a question, he will answer you patiently and send an announcement to clarify.
When final, he found out there are problems in marking, he remarked all the paper again (for the two questions which marked incorrectly by TAs)
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm(40%): 98/120 mean 71.8 SD: 18.9
Final(55%): 203/250 mean 178 SD: 36
IPRS(5%): 5/5 mean 4.3
Letter grade: A

reviews.author: Sunny Ng
reviews.title: Lenient grades with a heavy cost.
reviews.comment_content:
- Growth of energy consumption and population, fossil fuel powered machines
-Fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas
-Basic energy principles and thermodynamics, including 1st and 2nd law, heat engine efficiency
-Petrol and diesel engines for land and sea transport, gas turbine for air transport
-Electricity generation, motors, and electricity in Hong Kong
-Nuclear power and safety
-Renewable energy resources: water, wind, sunlight
-Impacts of energy use on the environment, emissions & global warming
-Environment issues in Hong Kong, PRD and the rest of the world

This course is just so bad. The course is basically "inspired" by a book written by an expert in energy and then taught as a common core course. To be frank, the course is neither interesting nor useful.

The course covers stuff about the above topics listed in some detail, but not detail enough to make the things we learn applicable in a useful way. For example, they just mention the famous E = mc equation but do not teach anything on how to use and apply it. They even like to present a lot of data in the slides. How do we even study them? Take a look at the attachment and see for yourself.

To your surprise, the things you learn during lectures aren't really the things that appear in the exams. For example, you learn about particulates in the air and their effects during lectures but they ask you to calculate the density of the particulates in the exam. This is as ridiculous as teaching stuff from one book and then asking questions from another.

This course is also very unprofessional. There are way too many assumptions and they make the calculations meaningless. Also, the words the course use are not precise. Once, there was a question that asked: "Which energy source is the most important?". Important in terms of what? How do you define important? This just makes students confused and then pisses them off.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Just look at other reviews. I'm not going to waste too much time on this.

The lecturers' monotone made their presentations plain. Sometimes, they couldn't even complete a sentence and they just moved on.

The funny thing is that they wrote stuff on the whiteboard, using a thin marker which barely had any ink in front of a Lecture Theatre with 400 seats. Of course, you could see what they were writing.

I'm sorry for being that harsh and sarcastic but I have wasted my youth on this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% PRS

There are PRS questions every lecture, so if you don't attend them you are losing marks. You get 1 mark if you get the answer right, half a mark if you get them wrong and nothing if you don't answer. This is the reason why students attend the lecture.

40% Mid-term exam
55% Final Exam

There are 2 parts, MC questions and Data-based (long) questions. The grading system is ridiculous. You get 5 marks for answering an MC question correctly, but somehow for whatever reason, they deduct 1 mark if you get it wrong. Then each long question is worth 5/10 marks with no partial credit. Just unbelievable.

But the grades are rather lenient. The mean is about a B and the difficulty is not high. It's more like a unit-conversion exam than a physics exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Apart from the PRS questions, which force you to attend every lecture, you have nothing to do outside of class.

To prepare for the exam, make sure you work on the homework they upload on Canvas. The homework may not be highly related to what is covered in the lecture but the lecturers somehow decide to ask similar questions in the exams. The content tested are not too in-depth and you get to prepare a 2-sided A4 size cheat sheet to the exam. Not much memorization is needed. Understanding is rather important here.

reviews.author: Kyu
reviews.comment_content:
I personally had interest, so the content of the course was quite interesting. It gives quantitative explanations of energy-related issues around us, and I was able to gain more knowledge about energy.

People might find it boring. Depends on personal preference.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching could improve.
Not the best teaching, but still the course itself is well organized, the professors are clear and precise about what they are talking about.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mean generally mediocre, and SD quite large.

You can definitely get high grades if you study hard enough.

PRS( A form of checking attendance Attendance): 5%
In the end of every lecture, there is about one or two problems students solve and submit answer through PRS. These questions are generally easy. Correct Answer: 1 points, Incorrect Answer: 0.5 point, and No Answer Submitted:0 points

Mid-term: 40%
The grade distribution almost followed a perfect Gauss model.

Finals: 50%
The exam is non-cumulative.
Showed Similar distribution to mid-term.
reviews.comment_workload: In terms of content, there are a lot of details you have to know in order to take mid term and finals. Each lecture ppts are fully packed with diagrams, details, and calculations. Although, you are able to have one sheet of A4 paper as your cheat sheet.

reviews.author: Cindy_
reviews.title: Learn by yourself
reviews.comment_content: The content itself is meaningful: a clear review of all types of energy and their effect on environment and human society. Yet it is not deep enough and too general, which is typical for ccc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Three professors teaching together makes it a little bit messy and disorganised. And the accent of certain professor needs improving badly, which may effect the quality of teaching.
The experiments at the beginning of lecture are not clearly demonstrated  and explained and it king of time-wasting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 188 out of 200
Final:       378 out of 400
PRS:       15 out of 17
Grade:     A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Relatively easy.
Exercises are optional but some questions may appear in exams even without changing the number.
You can bring cheatsheets to midterm and final exam.
Participation is assessed through PRS. (Lots of students just come to classroom to do the PRS and leave: also some bring several PRS including others.)

reviews.author: Low Jin
reviews.comment_content:
Although one A4 cheatsheet is allowed in the mid term and final, I personally think that the course syllabus is too broad even for those with physics background. However, this course is mainly about numbers and computations, so it should be fine for those who are sensitive to numbers.

PRS questions contribute up to 5% of the total mark.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture is generally boring and I think some lecturers may even read directly from the slides. I always ended up playing my phone or taking a nap till the end of the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is generally not bad for those who are good at computations.
reviews.comment_workload: The homework/assignments given are optional and for our own learning only. However, you may want to try them out, for there is at least one exam question (short q/long q) similar to the homework/assignments.

reviews.author: kwagor
reviews.comment_content:
As others concluded, this course is filled with fragmented contents, however luckily or unfortunately that this semester seemed to have a new grading system, a MT covers first half’s course (Up to engines) and the Final becomes a Project with 3 ppl maximum.

So, this course transform from exam type to a more balance one, thought I do think the MT content is the hardest part of the course, so it doesn’t mean it become easier, especially if you don’t good at physics, indeed you would have less to memorise.

Personally, I found the content is quite interesting, especially for the engines part, prof have a lots of videos played during lect to assist the flow of delivery.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think there is not much to complain about Prof Cheung’s delivery, and his time control is perfect, with very abundant assistance and consultation throughout the course contents, and there is lots of demo, and I think he nailed them, just as he did in PHYS1112.

TA is rather like a tool for the Prof, you wouldn’t have much interaction with them
reviews.comment_grading:
The new logistic as below:
IPRS 5% (only count after add/drop, total 18 tests; 1pts correct, 0.5 wrong; 0 missed)
MT 45% (Max 200 pts, mean 111.6)
Project 50% (8pts secured during the first 2 submission, 42pts report, mean 38)
As a total, estimated mean course mark = 78.825% (Assumed IPRS mean to be 5%)

There is no peer evaluation, and Prof states very clear at the start, if your grp mates free-ride, he can’t help, so be wise to fetch your team mates.

Advise: Try to find sb who show up in class frequently, if you studied with frds then awesome, try not to find grp mates from Civil Engineering or CS, unless you know them well.
reviews.comment_workload: If you get good group mates and have a clear mind to the project, then this course will be a very light workload course. But if you got some deadweights, then still a light workload course until the very last few weeks.

reviews.author: Michelle20
reviews.comment_content: The syllabus is quite broad, almost every lesson a new topic.

Umm... I would say just go read the ppt.
Lessons were quite boring and the prof. was just basically reading from the ppt.

The TA is quite good. He is willing to answer our questions even if they are stupid questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was fair.

Remember to attend lessons to do the polling, you score 1/1 for an correct ans, 0.5/1 for a wrong one and 0/1 for not answering.

For exams, a good cheatsheet is so so so important, so don't forget to spend time on making it during your revision.
Also, go through those hw questions and solutions before the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
No hw, one mid term and one final.
The mid term and the final is non cumulative.
The first mid term involves many calculation stuff, while the final is mostly about memorising.

reviews.author: CrabNebula
reviews.title: 2020-21 Fall semester (online)
reviews.comment_content:
Almost every comment are saying the same thing:
the course content is really fragmented.
Do not expect to learn much in this course, but take it for your grades.
Do not take it if you have not studied physics before. The content is meaningless.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Online class, no attendance needed, but they will give you a polling every lesson, 5% bonus.

I highly don't recommend anyone to listen. I personally consider this as a waste of time.

I am glad that this is an online class. All you have to do is sit in front of the computer (you may mute your computer if you like) and do other stuff while you wait for the polling window to pop up. The window pops up even if you are not opening the zoom meeting page. Then go google your answer.

TA (Leo) is really nice. He answers your questions very quickly and patiently through email. His answers are usually very detailed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Everyone score freaking high in the final. Pointless exam. The higher the score range, the more people lie in that range. Read the distribution graph for a laugh.

Midterm -- 45 %
Final -- 55 %
Polling -- 5 % bonus
All questions in the midterm and final are MCs. 5 marks for a correct answer, -1 for wrong, 0 for give up.

Midterm
Mean: 140/200
SD: 34
Final
Mean: 198/250
SD: 35

My score: 194/400 midterm 250/250 final. ~3% lesson bonus. Got A+. I cannot determine if this course has a lenient grading or not.

All I can say is, you do not have to remember the content in the lecture slides but instead you need to remember what is in there and where you can find your answers. Then PLEASE USE CTRL+F TO FIND YOUR ANSWERS FROM THE SLIDES during the exams. (online)
reviews.comment_workload: No workload at all. Do the assignments if you like, you don't need to hand in them.

reviews.author: 落車請早揚聲
reviews.title: 纯功利的讲，好课；但内容和lecture真的不敢恭维
reviews.comment_content: the content is mainly about energy and environment. but to be honest, although this course starts with "phys", I really dont think this is a physics course. except for the thermodynamics part, i would call the rest of the content a course about common knowledge, with lots of useless charts and statistics. （内地生的话要我说唯一比较物理的部分，看看高中选修3-5差不多了）
reviews.comment_teaching: Although Prof.Wang gave me an A+, I feel sorry but responsible to say that her teaching is terrible. Well in deed, because the content itself is very boring, I dont think there is much that the prof can do to make the lectures more interesting. But still, she is almost just reading along the ppt. And her English isn't good at all. I almost fell asleep in several lectures, if it wern't for the IPRS, I might skipped a lot of lessons. But she is a nice instructor and is willing to answer any of your questions. (even about the grading)
reviews.comment_grading:
the grading is said to be very good.
you can see the final exam distribution attached.
this sem, the grading was 45%midterm+55%final+5%IPRS bonus.(so technically you can get above 100%)

as for me, I got 4.7/5 in IPRS(polling), 177/200 in midterm (about mean+1.1sd) and 244/250 in final. I ended up with A+.

PS: Prof.Wang said usually the A range is around 25%, so it's not hard to get A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
almost 0.
Just attend the lectures and do the polling. There are HWs, but only for self practice, not need to hand in. the most workload that comes with this course would be preparing the cheatsheet before the midterm and finalexam(the cheat cheet must be hand written and you must hand in the cheatsheet before the exam or you may be deducted 10-20 points from the eventual score of your exam)

L1:      Introduction to the course and Population Growth

reviews.author: lonelyguy
reviews.comment_content:
This course will introduce the basic concepts of the physical principles behind energy. We will discuss various forms of energy and their use (including electricity, fossil energy, nuclear power, various forms of renewable energy), and their impacts on the environment both from a global and a regional perspective. We will discuss issues related to energy conservation and related environmental issues in Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta (PRD).

Course content:
- The growth of energy consumption and population, fossil fuel powered machines
- Fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas
- Basic energy principles and thermodynamics, including 1st and 2nd law, heat engine efficiency
- Petrol and diesel engines for land and sea transport, gas turbine for air transport
- Electricity generation, motors, and electricity in Hong Kong
- Nuclear power and safety
- Renewable energy resources: water, wind, sunlight
- Impacts of energy use on the environment, emissions & global warming
- Environment issues in Hong Kong, PRD and the rest of the world

reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading. Expected

Mid-term Exam:                  45%
Final Exam:                        55%
Plus 5% bonus by PRS quizzes

Full Marks for correct answers, half marks for incorrect answers, 0 marks for no answers.
Marks will not be counted during the add-drop period.

Exam: 5 marks added for correct answer and 1 mark deduction if you answer the questions wrongly in MC. +5 -1 system is the weirdest thing in this course. Long questions are difficult. Many calculations that do not mention in the lectures. Cheat sheet is allowed.

Final: Below 1.5 SD

Final Grade: C

Professor Cheung is a really good professor, but however the course is design badly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Gradings:
Mid-Term: 45%
Final: 55%
Polling: 5% Bonus

Mid-Term: 85% (Mean: 70%, SD:17%, +0.88 SD)
Final: 88.4% (Mean: 79.2%, SD:14%, +0.66 SD)
Polling: 94.12%
Total Score: 91.58%, A-

For Polling, they give 1 mark for correct answers and 0.5 mark for wrong answers. You would not want to miss the polling.
The final is very easy and most student performed well. The score distribution is even biased to the right. (See attached)
Mid-Term are not so easy and involved more calculations.

Cheatsheet and notes are allowed in the exam. I don't know why they forced students to submit cheatsheet even if the exam is open notes. It's a kind of wasting time to write cheatsheet. BTW only handwritten cheatsheets are allowed.

Poor Grading course.
fyi got 5 in DSE Phys

Nevertheless, since the course is basically Liberal Study mixed with some physics so it is not hard for you to attain B range if you just take a little bit of time studying lecture notes a few days before the exam.

reviews.author: kllauak
reviews.title: Take only if you have mastered other (harder) physics courses
reviews.comment_content:
The course starts with fossil fuels, then goes into car engines (which involve a lot of first and second law of thermodynamics). Electricity and renewable energy comes after the midterm.

Powerpoints are poorly compiled (equations show up as computer notation, e.g. fractions use"/", very difficult to interpret), the language used is full of grammatical mistakes that make the content very difficult to comprehend.
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring lecturers, poor spoken english, basically reading off powerpoints. Having 3 professors teaching is a mistake in the first place.
reviews.comment_grading:
Doing a proper physics course prior to taking this course is highly recommended. Not recommended to take if you are a business student or a first year engineering/physics student

Having mastery over course topics (by means of mastering other courses taught by more capable instructors) is crucial to getting a good grade. In fact no effort is needed by this method. There will be plenty of folks (like me) who did not know this trick beforehand to lower the mean score. As an engineering student myself, just doing the required physics course (PHYS1112) will have covered most of the math intensive parts of this course. I had no idea what I was doing on the midterm exam on the thermodynamics question. However I learnt all I needed to know for that question in PHYS1112, which was sadly taught after the midterm. If only I took this course after I had done PHYS1112, I would have gotten a much better grade

Peculiarities of the exams: 5 marks for correct and -1 for incorrect choice for MC part, no marks deducted for wrong answers in the written section. Bonus points (max 5%) for doing the PRS questions.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework is optional and it does not help in understanding course material anyway. Again, if you have mastered course topics from other courses, you do not have to put any effort into this course. You do not even have to go to the lectures. All you need to do is show up to the exam. Consider this to be an exam of the utmost basic content from other physics courses.

reviews.author: max
reviews.title: Good grade but boring
reviews.comment_content: To get good grade, just work hard to remember many numbers cuz you cannot print every thing on cheat sheet
reviews.comment_teaching: It's one of the most boring lectures I have ever taken but the PRS test forces us to take the lecture lol
reviews.comment_grading: good. It seems that there is about 40% A range.So it won't be difficult to get A range, but it is hard to get  an  A+
reviews.comment_workload: Wow you can play computer on the lecture but you need to remember a lot of things before the exam.

reviews.author: AAAAAA
reviews.comment_content: It's just common sense course. Content is very easy, you have to remember a lot, but the calculations and formula are relatively easy. But you can have a double-sided A4 cheat sheet for both midterm and final (non-accumulative). Just put everything on the cheat sheet, but I did reorganize the material.
reviews.comment_teaching: Content is easy and boring, everything is on the lecture notes. So most of the time, professors are just reading the notes. But they are trying to make the course interesting and you can see that. For example, class demonstrations, videos and so on.
reviews.comment_grading: Mean is low, sd is very high. But if you are almost mean+ 1 sd, you will probably get an A. But if you want to get A+, maybe 1.5 sd? Because although mean is low, the highest score is always very high, you can guess that's why sd is high and how many people got high marks.
reviews.comment_workload: You just have to go over the notes and put them on the cheatsheet. No assignment. But you'd better do the homework, cuz some questions are in the exams. I think most people will find it too easy to go over the materials once and once again. But I do suggest you review it after each class, because if you put all of these during exam period, you will find the materials too many to read and you don't even want to read it. They use PRS to record attendance and you have to get the questions right to get full mark. As the course is relatively easy, make sure you go to the lectures and get the questions right.

reviews.title: Fall sem is Good grade, but a boring course.
reviews.comment_content: This course is talking about the energy, for example, the light energy, etc. If fact you don't need to know the things precisely to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring, just read ppt out. It is not necessary to listen to the lesson since copy whole ppt into cheatsheet is enough.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good. Mean is B. Above mean a bit can get A range. (It is very easy to get above mean if you look through the ppt once, or even just look through few topics, bcs the exam's long q is super easy, very basic calculation, easier than high school level.) I haven't revise for the final exam and get below mean, still get a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Just copy all the things into cheatsheet can guarantee you to get at least A range. The most annoying things is the PRS so that you need to attend the lesson every time to do your own things.

reviews.author: @Jerome
reviews.comment_content:
CONTENT
The content is pointless and disorganized. You are intended to learn about physics related to energy production and related issues, but the content is a crap of mess that I learn nothing useful at the end of semester. In this course, you’ll learn some thermodynamics, DSE physics (E3 module especially) and some social-related issues which are freaking pointless.

reviews.author: Eddy
reviews.title: Good grade but BORING course
reviews.comment_content: The content is similar to the energy electives for HKDSE, and it was not very difficult to study it on your own. You'll be delighted with the content if you love physics.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lesson is extremely boring, with poor English accent from the professors, you could barely understand what they are talking about, so brace yourself to study the course materials on your own for exams.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading of this course is fantastic. My friend got an A with just above mean for a little bit for both mid term and final. Cheat sheet is allowed during exams, so it is not that hard to prepare for exams. It is quite hard to get an A+ though.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is low for this course, mid term, final and prs after every lesson.

reviews.author: MM
reviews.title: Very rubbish course!
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is boring and rubbish. He would just read out all things in the PPT, and if somethings that are difficult appear, he would simply say just take it for granted without explanations.

I know many students say PHY1003 is good grade, but i would say it only suitable to students with science background (I am not saying DSE phy, as many materials are new and I don't think I would be fine if I have DSE physic background)
reviews.comment_grading:
40% by Midterm Exam

55% by Final Exam

5% by PRS quizzes

Grading is simple, all focuses on exam. However, I would say SBM or non science background students would have comparative disadvantage in grading, as we have limited knowledge in Physics and science, students from SENG and SCI will be killing you easily in exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Very very light, actually no workload. It had some optional exercises but not compulsory, answers will be released after one week. Also, you can have cheat sheet for both midterm and final, no much memorization is required.

reviews.author: SnaKe
reviews.title: 好grade的cc
reviews.comment_content: midterm前考1-11課，final考12-23(睇attachment)。內容大部dse phy都接觸過，不過依家再深入d。計數方面要多加留意，short q有機會問，盡量每堂教完都睇下。mc問題notes會搵到，考前抄落cheatsheet。建議讀左phys1112先讀
reviews.comment_teaching: 其實都幾悶下，prof照住ppt讀，又要你禁prs（上堂自修其他科啦）。不過prof都幾願意答問題。
reviews.comment_grading: 堅好grade，六百幾人讀的course都唔差得去邊......我自己兩次exam都高1.6sd，最後A+。phy底唔差的同學建議讀，如果想拎好grade嘅話就自己整cheatsheet啦。
reviews.comment_workload: 平時真係冇workload，assignment又唔洗交，岩讀18credit的人。exam又俾你拎張cheatsheet，電腦print出黎都得，只係exam前整cheatsheet會用多d時間。

reviews.author: IRkyIS
reviews.title: Sorry this comment is for PHYS 1001
reviews.comment_content:
Sorry this comment is for PHYS 1001

many topics covered
even though the course is designed for students who haven't studied phys, some topics are even out of the HKDSE syllabus.

The course only test your knowledge in concept, but for those who do not have any knowledge in science, you have to put a lot of effort on studying the concepts.  

IF YOU DON'T LIKE PHYS OR SCIENCE, DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE. There are more options in CC or even in the S&T aspect.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sorry this comment is for PHYS 1001


nothing special, he is just reading ppt. It is really sleepy especially for 9am lecture.

He is not likely to answer your questions except during the lecture time and ask in the chat box in zoom.

But videos are useful in explaining some of the content of the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Sorry this comment is for PHYS 1001

For there have calculation question maybe will be better.

For online exam, it has no chance for you to return to the previous questions.

All MC questions (in IRPS of the lectures and tutorials, midterm and final exam as well.

The mean is high, may be some of the students has some phys or science knowledge but not recognize by HKUST. In every lectures and labs, i am just being very confused that everyone seems picking up very fast, even for questions that he had never mentioned in lectures.
reviews.comment_workload:
Sorry this comment is for PHYS 1001

The course is a typical exam based course.

However, except mid term and final exam, there are a few questions in every lectures. You have to attend every lectures and participant in the IPRS, and it will only count for your correct answers.

Also, every tutorials would be a mini quiz on the content you have learned in that week. In an one-hour tutorial, you have to answer 10 questions in IPRS, and the TA will explain the concept.
